We are going to be the Argentina of the 21st century, at the rate we're going—and it won't take long, with you guys. It's not going to take long, with you guys, to drive us into the ground, because you guys have no idea what you're talking about. You're ideological fools.

You will reverse course on this bill before 2030 because we are going to see jobs driven out of this country. As we transition from the cheap, reliable base load energy to renewable energy—this is on top of the cost-of-living pressures. We have an RBA that's jacked up interest rates by 10 per cent, on the back of all this crazy spending from COVID forced on us by the crazy Labor premiers. This is going to end very badly, very soon.

For you guys to be sitting over there laughing, mark my words that the day will come when we look back on you guys and we won't be laughing. We'll be shaking our heads going, 'Why on earth did we let this happen?' And you're sitting there all buried in your phones because you know you can't justify this bill, because you don't have the intelligence or the integrity to explain this bill. You cannot explain how sticking a carbon tax on industry—
The DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Sorry, senator. Yes, Minister?
Senator Gallagher: On a point of order. Senator Rennick should be directing his remarks through the chair and not directly across the chamber.
The DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Thank you for that guidance.

Senator RENNICK: I should have gone through the chair. Silly me to think that the other side would not be so fragile and brittle as to have to get petty. That's because they can't handle the fact, Mr Deputy President, that they don't want to be scrutinised. They can't explain how sticking a tax on industry for a gas that yet again—we were taught in grade 8: it's called photosynthesis; it's plant food—is a natural part of the environment. Who on Earth would come up with this sort of idea, to tax something that's a natural part of the environment? Who would do that? Only a party that doesn't care for our children's future or our country's future. All they are going to do is empower other countries that will end up taking us over one way or the other—if they want to. I mean, why they'd bother coming here I don't know. They'd take one look at the people in power at the moment and they'd run a mile. Who would want to come to this country?

The other thing—this is what I love about Labor policy—is that it is so inconsistent. They're out there skiting about how they've got a high immigration rate, right? They're saying, 'Oh, we've got 300,000 immigrants coming in again.' If you wanted to reduce emissions, wouldn't you actually lower immigration? Wouldn't you lower immigration? And while you're at it, stick a tax on the universities that don't pay tax on all these fees they earn from foreign students, okay? Why don't you get the universities to pay for all the extra demands from these students as they come in and take houses? I mean, you're going to put this housing fund up—yet again, more contradictions from the Labor Party: high immigration that puts pressure on the cost of living, pressure on housing. What are you going to do about it? More immigration, because of course they can always then get the immigrants. They meet them at the border and say, 'Vote for us; we're Labor; we're gonna look after you.'

And of course it's false-economy stuff. It's all false-economy stuff, because this party has no idea what they're doing. They don't understand economics. They don't understand science. They don't understand patriotism They are an absolute, utter disgrace that has basically got to ram this legislation through in the dead of night. They don't want anyone listening to any speeches, because they don't want any scrutiny, because they can't answer the questions, but they are sticking a tax on the Australian people, because other people on the other side of the world have said so. You don't answer to the Australian people. You don't have any loyalty to this country. Shame on you.

Senator McDONALD (Queensland) (00:52): Well, the Albanese government's safeguard mechanism is the most egregious attack on Australian investment, Australian jobs and Australian prosperity. Australians and our First World standard of living are being sold out by a Labor-Greens government, so deaf to industry concerns and to the threat to Australian jobs and so determined to impose its extreme ideology that's willing to sacrifice our most important industries, to damage small business and to send families broke. And at a time when cost of living is eroding household budgets at a rate of knots, Prime Minister Albanese and Minister Bowen have signed a dodgy deal with the Greens, and they're ramming through these laws that just add to this pain.

The Labor Party is captive to the Greens, and the Greens are captive to the renewable energy industry. The government's approach to the cost-of-living crisis is forcing our most productive and job-creating industries to pay a new tax to meet overambitious emissions goals, and the resources sector's royalties and PRRT, corporate payroll and PAYG taxes pay for Australia's First World lifestyle—the public health and education, the roads and the NDIS, and that, by the way, is 40 per cent of Australia's company tax takes, and their employee PAYG take contributes the same proportion.

This sector operates to the highest mining safety and environmental standards in the world. It is the mining industry that employs the environmental scientists, carries out the rehab projects and funds community engagement. Once Australia's golden child, the resources sector is now the whipping boy of an administration that is consumed by the fantasies that it can tax its way to prosperity. What makes Labor's gas-phobic approach more nonsensical is that even the European Union has labelled gas a green source of energy. Even though Germany is recommissioning coal-fired power stations, and the UK is rationing energy, even after spending hundreds of billions of euros on decarbonising, Labor somehow thinks Australia is immune from the same economic realities.

The safeguard mechanism is not about decarbonisation; it is about deindustrialisation. It will cripple Australia's resources and manufacturing sector, making our country a worse place. All Labor and the Greens have succeeded in doing is putting a hard cap on future economic growth, because, if industries cannot develop in Australia, they will look to move overseas. This safeguard mechanism will export Australian resources jobs and import Chinese-made renewables. Labor talks about transitioning resources jobs to new jobs, but what jobs exactly does Labor propose that will replace mining jobs, which are paid at double the rate of the average Australian wage? I wonder if the CFMMEU and the AWU have given their blessing to this anti-investment, antijob legislation.

This is a government that is so light on business experience that it has no understanding of the incredible competition for investment dollars in this world. And what are businesses saying? Bowen Coking Coal CEO Nick Jorss said:

span.span: it's fanciful to think that reducing our high-quality exports in the face of record demand will do anythin
g other than drive up energy and steel prices, create a net increase global emissions and destroy Australian jobs, both in regions and in cities.

p.span: President of Peabody's Australian operations, Jamie Frankcombe, said the company was concerned the legislation would:
… make the mining industry less competitive at a time when it's integral to providing the minerals and energy required for the energy transition.
… it will reduce our cost competitiveness, lead to potential job losses and hurt regional communities.

Industry is telling the government that this legislation is a direct threat to the jobs and investment that the resources sector provides—jobs and investment that support regional Australia and drive our economic growth.

We warned that a Labor government would have the Greens writing resources policy—and, as I've described it before, we have the Greens tail wagging the Labor dog. The Labor Party has never sought to engage the coalition in these discussions. We warned Australia before the election that, if Labor were elected, the Greens would be writing Australia's resources policies, and this has turned out to be true. The coalition highlighted our concerns on a 43 per cent emissions reduction target for 2030 well before the election and have not changed from that position. We supported a measured, cooperative approach to net zero by 2050, using technology to reduce our emissions—and they were reducing. This latest deal between Labor and Greens is simply a doubling down on bad policy. Prices will go up. Investment will go down. Emissions will be sent offshore and multiply. The Greens' demands on the safeguard mechanism will only worsen our impending energy and gas crisis, yet the government appears to be diving headlong into these looming shortages.

At a time when AEMO is warning of gas shortages, these policy settings will result in investment dollars being allocated to other projects, not here in Australia. Many resource companies have described to me the difficulty in convincing their shareholders and investment boards to continue investing in Australian projects that have increasing costs of electricity, industrial relations uncertainty, approval delays and now a carbon tax on emissions. They describe attempting to tell the government that they can't meet the emissions reductions in these ridiculous time lines, and Labor's response is to lift the big stick of penalties higher. This may suit the Greens, considered by their European counterparts to be the most extreme socialist party, but it will be devastating for Australians who have come to enjoy our comfortable lifestyle. Labor have touted the importance of gas as a future fuel source. The PM, the energy minister and the resources minister all highlight this, but it is apparent they continue to ignore industry and the warning signs the coalition have been pointing out over the last 10 months.

The safeguards mechanism is simply another burden on the gas industry that is already struggling against bad Labor policies. Let's list them: market intervention, NOPSEMA reviews and callings, mandatory code of conduct and reasonable pricing provisions, ADGSM reforms, funding environmental lawfare groups and the creation of a new environmental protection agency. AEMO, the ACCC, APPEA gas companies and the coalition have all been warning Labor that their policies are making the gas market worse. The continued interventions are, in fact, leading to reduced supply, less investment certainty, higher prices and fewer jobs, and all of this eventually leads to blackouts and rationing.
As APPEA's CEO, Samantha McCulloch, said:
… the Labor-Greens deal creates additional barriers to investment, further diminishing the investment environment and adding to the growing list of regulatory challenges facing the sector …
Today in the Australian, she said:

The safeguard mechanism announcement is the latest example of government action not matching the rhetoric. Just see the trend of cascading interventions in the domestic gas market while the Australian Competition & Consumer Commission, AEMO and the government are all stressing the need for new gas supply.
This is a government that can't manage the energy market. It is a government that is putting Australian jobs on the line, future investment on hold and Australia's future prosperity at risk.

The next budget will be built on the strength of the resources sector, a sector that brings in $450 billion in export earnings in 2022-23. A sector that makes up 13 per cent of our GDP. A sector that supports over 1.1 million well-paid Australian jobs. We know that gas is a flexible, reliable fuel source that is vital for manufacturing, for baseload supply and for heating, and yet Labor is bent on demonising this industry. And if Australia becomes an untenable investment location, producers will move offshore. This means emissions will move offshore as well, not go down, and gas will become more expensive if we are forced to import supply. We don't even have the infrastructure to import gas to the market.

Labor promised a dream to Australians less than 12 months ago, and how quickly that has become a nightmare. It's a nightmare where industry emissions are exported from Australia to higher emitting countries; where jobs are created in China and India and lost in Australia. It is beyond arrogant to suggest that winning government with the lowest primary vote in decades gives you a mandate to completely up-end Australia's way of life in this matter, and for no guarantee of better environmental outcomes.

Prime Minister, I urge you to abandon this headlong, crazy rush to a jobless, Greens-led future and instead encourage businesses to operate in the most cost-effective, efficient and sustainable manner possible. Families, business owners, workers and shareholders rely on strong resources and mining companies operating with confidence and certainty. But Australians must be told the real price of the safeguard mechanism under Labor and the Greens, the real price of investment moving from this country to other jurisdictions, the loss of jobs and the increase in the cost of living. I think that price is too high. I think that those opposite, who are laughing listening to me, demonstrate their lack of understanding of how fragile the investment world is. I think Australians will understand the cost of this policy. The cost of this policy will be real jobs for real Australians. Because of the increased costs BCA members will buy credits, buy offsets and pass them through to Australians in higher costs of living.

Those from the other side have no understanding of how dangerous this policy is. These companies are telling me that they cannot get the government to understand that their investment boards are saying we have other options. We have hundreds of projects that are available in the US for gas, in Indonesia for coal, in South America for copper. They have choices. When their boards are looking at the sovereign risk that Australia is now providing they are saying that they will choose somewhere else.

In parts of regional Queensland Australians are already getting the bad news from small gas produces that their investors have pulled out, that they cannot get investors to underwrite the sort of market intervention that this government has introduced. If you don't believe me, I will give you their names—the names of families who are already feeling the pain of this government's intervention. For those people that price is too high. Unfortunately, the rest of Australia is starting to wake up and is starting to see the cost of this Labor Greens coalition and the devastating impact on Australian investment, Australian jobs, Australian taxes and Australian lifestyles.

Senator LIDDLE (South Australia) (01:07): I have actually worked in one of those global companies that packed up and went somewhere else amid operating uncertainty. It was a very fast action. It was in your own state of South Australia, Senator Grogan. This bill will damage Australian industries, threaten thousands of Australian jobs and particularly have an adverse impact on some important industries in my home state of South Australia—the industries I have actually worked in. I have had a very, very diverse career. I can talk with some credibility.

The coalition supports action on climate change, but with a sensible transition to net zero emissions which protects Australian jobs, our towns and our regions. Yes, careful management is required to ensure Australia's industries progress while remaining strong and prosperous. Businesses directly targeted by this legislation believe this will, for them, drive up the cost of energy, destroy jobs and stifle or even kill foreign investment. In short, it will damage prosperity.

We live in a global economy and with that the reality is that businesses can go elsewhere if the numbers do not stack up, because, unlike the Australian Greens and the Albanese Labor government, they are not given by ideology. Reducing carbon emissions is important. This does nothing to combat the global problem of emissions.

In government, the coalition met and exceeded Australia's Kyoto targets, signed Australia up to achieving net zero by 2050, reduced emissions by more than 20 per cent on our 2005 base level and was well on track to beat Paris treaty commitments.

Words are important. These 215 companies are not just emitters, they are employees, contributors to local, regional and the national economy and contributors by way of wages and taxes, so that Australians can maintain our standard of living—though fast eroding. Under the coalition emissions reductions were driven by the Emissions Reduction Fund, which supported voluntary action by landholders, businesses and communities. In contrast, Labor's changes to the safeguard mechanism will force facilities to reduce their emissions intensity by up to 4.9 per cent each year, regardless of whether the technology exists for them to do so. Failure to meet the government's emission targets or purchase the necessary amount of offsets will see a business fined $275 per tonne. This idea presents unacceptable risk and in fact risks Australia's sovereign manufacturing capabilities, which we have been hearing from Labor are so important to it and to this country. In this time of uncertainty, even fools know that higher costs in production will be passed on and will impact along the supply chain, and eventually it will hit everyday consumers.

Labor's claim that its safeguard mechanism policy mirrors the coalition's is misleading. There has been insufficient assessment of the impacts of this reform. It is not equitable for Australian industries, and there is no detail on costs. The safeguard mechanism first introduced by the former coalition government has been working for years, providing a system to cap emissions while still encouraging the economy to grow. The coalition's approach was one that appreciated that each business was different and needed time to change to comply and to invest in the technology needed, if indeed it existed. It was an approach that understood the realities of operating businesses by backing them to develop the technology. But this is a blunt instrument that penalises business and imposes more taxes. The former coalition government laid out a plan to achieve net zero by 2050 without new taxes. It supported a carbon trading system that rewarded businesses that voluntarily reduced their emissions. It provided a plan to create incentives and support businesses that made the transition to net zero. What is proposed here is a tax, as only Labor knows how to do so effectively—tax, tax and more tax.

As if higher and rising energy prices and significant labour shortages are not enough, now businesses have to contend with this tax and compete against producers in other countries where regulation is almost non-existent and where there are lower wages and production costs. We rely on trade with others. We are an open economy. Pricing carbon at $75 a tonne means Australia will have a price that is three times as high as the one set by the previous Labor government, and it could rise to $100 a tonne by 2030. It is also much higher than the carbon prices of eight of Australia's top 10 two-way trading partners. Many of our trading partners and international competitors for key industries, including alumina, cement, copper, coal, gas and iron ore, do not have any national carbon pricing scheme in place at all. This legislation delivers them even greater competitive advantage.

Nyrstar, SIMEC, Santos, Hallett Concrete, Adelaide Brighton Cement and Kimberly-Clark—to name some—are companies operating in my home state that will be impacted by this legislation. It would also have an immediate and direct effect on the towns of Whyalla and Port Pirie and on the Yorke Peninsula. Change always has consequences, both intentional and unintentional. I've been contacted directly by companies who are concerned about their ability to remain competitive and are working through very real scenarios that include the prospect of shutting up or moving out. The sovereign risk is also very real. These are businesses with long histories that make decisions on the basis of opportunity cost, sunk costs and economic reality.

This could not be happening at a worse time than this time of economic instability through rising costs and changes in the regulatory environment. It risks the jobs of thousands of Australians—yes, real jobs. Tonight we have seen the Australian Greens celebrate what they say will be the shutting down of projects in coal and gas. There is little regard for workers, families and communities who rely on the coal industry, which employed 46,000 people in 2022. The Australian gas industry supply chain directly employs 165,000 Australians. They too won't be joining the Australian Greens as they celebrate.

You know who else won't be celebrating? Try the producers of concrete and mortar. Those are the materials for the bridges we need built, the pavers we walk on and the houses we live in. What they see is cheaper imports of cement and other masonry products flooding into the Australian market, products manufactured offshore where there is no impost on emissions—in effect, increasing global omissions while crippling Australian businesses.

This legislation means that for cement industries there is the very real prospect of importing a critical ingredient called clinker. By manufacturing it here, at least they get to control the quality, the compressive strength and the setting properties of that cement. If they buy the product from overseas, there is less control. These are the decisions they'll have to make.

Adelaide Brighton Cement is one of Australia's largest cement, lime, concrete and masonry producers, with its base in my home town of Adelaide. It has other production plants around the country. It is a company employing almost 2,000 people on full-time basis in SA, with a total gross value of $515 million to the state. Around the nation, Adbri employs over 11,000 people and provides a total gross value of $3.1 billion to the Australian economy. It has been implementing strategies to reduce emissions but expects that this 4.9 per cent annual decrease in emissions by 2030 will place the company at risk and make it less competitive than overseas importers. It is now, in effect, being punished for almost totally converting its plants to gas rather than coal and for making significant inroads in the use of lower-carbon alternative fuels.

Another company is Nyrstar, a global multimetal business employing 1,300 people in Australia, with more than 800 people at its Port Pirie plant in South Australia and another 500 at its Hobart plant—real people, real jobs. Nyrstar Port Pirie is meeting the global demand for metals that are critical to the world's decarbonised future. Zinc, lead and copper are products particularly in demand for the production of things like batteries, cabling and other components for electrical products. Just like Adelaide Brighton Cement, Nyrstar has worked on lessening its carbon footprint. It says the time frame is unreasonable. You'd know that if you worked in the industry or consulted it, rather than consulting your union masters or the Greens. The fact that the Port Pirie site uses pyrometallurgical processes means it is hard to abate because the technology is not there yet.

These are very real issues, and they are amplified and articulated clearly in submissions to the Senate Environment and Communications Legislation Committee, which looked at the implications of this bill. The Business Council of Australia warned—you heard the South Australian examples, I'm sure—
Senator Grogan interjecting—

Senator LIDDLE: President, going through you. The Business Council of Australia warned the emissions decline rate for industrial facilities of 4.9 per cent annually will be 'challenging' for many industries. We know that's code for 'the costs will be passed on'.

Again in my home state, the forestry industry is worth $1.4 billion in revenue. You want more houses? It takes 17 trees on average to build a house, and the industry supplies your toilet paper and cork. They will be impacted by this. The Australian Forest Products Association argues that this is being implemented too quickly, without due consideration of the consequences and possible outcomes.

This Albanese government has already hit Australian households with higher costs of living and is determined to hit them again. Its carbon tax will lead to more expensive building materials, and, don't you know, in the middle of a housing affordability crisis; higher transport and fuel costs in response to rising energy bills; and higher food costs as supply chains respond to the reality of these changes.

We know that the producers of cement, steel and aluminium are large employers and hard-to-abate sectors. They know what's coming from this. They have told us. The coalition understands Australians want action on climate change, but those same Australians deserve to know the cost to them under Labor's plans. Where is the evidence of the impact on the Australian economy? Where? Where is the Treasury modelling? Where is it? Where is the modelling on the carbon credit market impact? Not there. Haven't seen it.

There are too many risks outlined by the people who run the businesses that this policy is intending to impact, and too many unanswered questions in Labor's climate policy. Not good for you, not good for businesses you rely on, not good for your purse or your hip pocket—but how much, during this time of great uncertainty and high costs, is something you are yet to find out. There are too many issues and there is too little information to even consider this bill. For South Australians, for Australian industry and for Australians, our response must be no.

Senator CHANDLER (Tasmania) (01:20): I rise this morning to make a contribution on the Safeguard Mechanism (Crediting) Amendment Bill 2023. In my first speech to this place almost four years ago, I spoke about a number of different things, but one thing I was particularly passionate about—and still am particularly passionate about—are the opportunities that have been provided to my home state of Tasmania as a result of strong coalition governments, and the detriment to my home state when it is led by Labor-Greens minority governments. I made many references in that first speech to the period of 2010 to 2014 when Tasmania was led by a Labor-Greens minority government at a state level and, to an extent, at a federal level, and the impacts that had on my home state. Industries were being shut down. Unemployment was absolutely through the roof. More people were leaving Tasmania than were coming in. That was a result of the Labor-Greens minority government and the job-destroying policies that they implemented in Tasmania.

I'm very sad to say that this morning, with this bill, history is repeating itself. This is the week where the Labor government has stopped even pretending to be on the side of jobs and investment and has announced that they are just on the side of the Greens. Yesterday—sorry, given that it's almost 1.30am, I should say the day before yesterday—we had the Albanese government's new policy on this safeguarding mechanism announced by the Greens leader in a Greens press conference. This is a week in which the Labor Party's entire agenda is predicated on doing deals with the Greens.

In an election campaign, Labor goes round telling Australians that they're not like the Greens, and that they know the Greens are job destroyers and that the Greens hate many of our key industries and want to shut them down. But, when they get into government, the first thing Labor do is get into a back room with the Greens and tell them that they are on the same team, and ask them, 'What do we need to give you in order for you to let us ram legislation though this parliament?' That is exactly what happened following the last election, and that is exactly what is happening with this bill that we are debating in the Senate right now.

The Labor government wants to pretend that they are in support of manufacturing. Yet, they are doing deals with the Greens that are going to make it harder and more expensive for manufacturing businesses to operate in Australia. They want to pretend they're on the side of the mining industry, but then they do a deal with the Greens to stop new mining ventures and put huge pressure on existing ones. The Greens are openly boasting that Labor has done a deal with them to stop new mining and gas projects. How many jobs is that going to kill off? What impact will that have on cost of living for Australians? How much more expensive is it going to make our energy prices, which we know are already skyrocketing under Labor.

As I said in my opening remarks, coming from Tasmania I know all too well—and Tasmanians know all too well—the damage that is done to an economy when Labor and the Greens team up. Entire industries, like the forestry industry, are completely decimated. A generation of tradies pack up and move to the mainland, because there isn't enough work in Tasmania. This was the case historically. The Labor party sent a message to business that their priority was staying in power with the help of the Greens. The result was businesses packed up or were forced out of business by those job-destroying policies of the Labor-Greens government. If you genuinely want to send a message to Australian workers in mining—or in forestry or agriculture or aquaculture or manufacturing or any of the industries that are incredibly important to our economy—that you support them, the absolute last thing you would do is a deal with the Greens, yet that is exactly what the Albanese Labor government has done. Of course, it's not just one deal. We've already seen, on numerous occasions, Labor going to the Greens and giving them exactly what they want in order to push legislation through this parliament. What happens next time Labor goes to the Greens for help, rushing a bill through the parliament or rushing a bill through this place? We know the Greens will ask for more concessions. Another set of businesses will all of a sudden find the government has thrown them under the bus to get the Greens' support.

We've already seen this happen with the forestry industry. At election time Mr Albanese claimed to be a big supporter of the native forest industry. He said, 'I will take up the fight against the Greens to protect your job.' What an absolute joke! He's not taking the fight up to the Greens. He's doing deals with them. He did a deal on the Reconstruction Fund with the Greens to prohibit native forest logging being supported. If the Prime Minister were a big supporter of the native forestry industry, as the Prime Minister claims, why would he do a deal with the Greens to exclude that industry's involvement in a fund like this? As the Australian Forest Products Association said:

Australian industry and Australian jobs should never be used as a Senate bargaining-chip. It's a slippery slope which can only end in tears for our economy. It's time to start staring the Greens down.

Well, far from being stared down, it is the Greens who are staring down the Labor government, and it's the Labor government which is backing down and giving the Greens what they want. That is why this parliamentary week started with the Greens holding a press conference, announcing that they'd got what they wanted from the Labor government. We're going to see this pattern over and over and over again throughout this term of the parliament. Labor ministers and Labor members are going to go out and announce a bill, pretending that they are backing Australian workers and backing Australian families, knowing all the while that when the bill comes to this place, the Senate, when we get in here, they will be giving the Greens what they want.

When it comes to climate policy and reducing emissions, the government of Australia is really just going along with whatever the Greens want. The people of Australia expect the government to do whatever it can to keep energy prices low. Labor knows that. That's why they deliberately misled the public by promising to cut power bills by $275 a year—a promise they've already broken and clearly never intended to keep. It's also the government's job to make sure that job-creating industries are supported to continue employing Australians. But here, with this legislation tonight—this morning, I mean—we have the Greens and the government making it more difficult for some of our biggest industries to keep employing Australians into the future.

What's worse is that this is a hypocritical government. They've gone around the world telling other nations how bad Australia allegedly was under the previous government, even though the facts are that we reduced emissions by over 20 per cent on our 2005 base level. We outperformed nearly all other countries. Of course, while Labor has been going around the region telling everyone how bad Australia has been, what they're not telling other countries is that the Chinese government is operating dozens of new coal-fired power plants every year.

The Labor-Greens safeguard mechanism policy turns a mechanism that was working well to support business to invest in new technology into a punitive tax which will put a wrecking ball through the Australian economy. Businesses that are already whacked with huge energy price increases as a result of this government are now going to have a new carbon tax to pay. Labor is determined to make Australian business uncompetitive. The $75 carbon tax is significantly higher than the carbon prices of eight of Australia's top 10 two-way trading partners, putting our industries at a significant disadvantage. Many of our trading partners and international competitors for key industries do not have any national carbon pricing scheme in place at all. Our exporters will struggle to compete in these markets against lower-cost rivals. That means not only less export revenue but less investment and fewer jobs.

Australian businesses are at risk of closing down after being rendered uncompetitive by Labor's policies and the Greens policies that we are seeing enacted here through the Labor government tonight. This economic activity will relocate overseas to markets with no climate policies and high emissions intensities, in many cases more than double the emissions of Australian companies. What does that mean? It means Australians are going to lose their jobs, the businesses that employ them will shift overseas and Labor and Greens politicians will be bragging about what a great job they've done in cutting emissions. When those jobs shift overseas, perhaps to places like China, which is dramatically increasing its emissions, not cutting them, the environment will be worse off, because they have no interest in cutting emissions.

The other major impact is going to be on Australian households. Under the Albanese government, families are getting hit with skyrocketing power bills, grocery bills, mortgage bills and rent payments. This government promised it would cut the cost of living but has done the complete opposite. Now they want to make it worse. When you put new taxes on business and increase their costs, they have no alternative but to pass those costs to the consumer, which is going to mean even higher prices, directly caused by the government, for food, for energy and for Australian-made products. This is a tax that fundamentally will end up hitting all Australians in the hip pocket.

In summary, like I said, this has been a very sad week for Australians. This is a week in which the government's entire agenda has been surrendered and predicated on dirty deals done with the Greens. We had an election campaign where Labor went around telling Australians that they weren't like the Greens, that they were going to be better than the Greens and that they weren't going to shut down key industries because of the Greens, yet we are in this place now debating a piece of legislation as a result of a deal with the Greens that is going to do exactly that—absolute shame on this government.

Senator CADELL (New South Wales—Nationals Whip in the Senate) (01:34): I'm sorry to everyone who has to come in here at 1.30 in the morning to hear what I think is a mediocre speech that I've written! What we're looking at tonight, with this Safeguard Mechanism (Crediting) Amendment Bill 2023, is more about de-industrialisation than about decarbonisation. It's more of an attack on businesses and their ROIs than it is on any CO2. For too long, Labor governments have taken our country's industrial might for granted, assuming that it'd always be there. But, in reality, de-industrialising will have disastrous consequences for our economy and our way of life.

This bill has some good ideas: let's clean up the economy, let's do these things and let's clean up some emissions. But the way the government is proposing to do it is overkill. I think, at 1.30 in the morning, when we're a bit tired and a bit emotional, it's always the time for a really bad analogy, like one about dogs or something like that. I've been watching Facebook ads, as we've been going through, and there are these salt guns, with laser sights, that kill flies. I think that's a really good idea. You can get these little salt guns and hit a fly that's flying through your room—and I think Labor has had a good idea on emissions: 'We're going to get rid of emissions. We're going to get a salt gun.' But they've got a real shotgun. They're going to shoot it through the wall, and they don't care who they get on the other side or what they get around it. They don't care about the unintended consequences. They don't see through to what their actions could actually do; they only see what they want them to do.

What this is going to do to Australia, what it's going to do to my home in the Hunter Valley and what it's already doing is devastating. Orica is one of the companies that came to us, face to face, and I raised this the other day. Orica produce ammonium nitrate. They're one of the few companies that do it in Australia, but they're up against a big problem. Russia, of all countries, is appealing antidumping laws at the moment. Russia, even with their 35 per cent tax, has previously won an appeal against antidumping laws. They flame off their gas, they do all this overseas and they dump their ammonium nitrate in Australia, and Orica are trying to compete with that, day by day. What are we doing? We are sitting here and, with this bill, making it harder for them.

Part of this bill includes a grandfathering clause. We've talked about all sorts of things here, but, specifically, if we look forward, there was going to be an exclusion for contracts that were already entered into under the safeguard mechanism. That was great for Orica. They had until 2029 under their contracts. So they invested, they put money into the Kooragang Island Walsh Point plant in Newcastle and they made it one of the cleanest, best, most efficient plants for ammonium nitrate in the world. It's not cheaper than in Russia, because Russia has gas everywhere and they can do what they want. But it was efficient, it was clean and it was good for the world. But now, under this plan, the government is going to grandfather contracts for only two years. So the certainty that Orica had for six years is gone, and they'll have that certainty for only two years.

I have my plan in the Hunter Valley; it's there. People will stay employed, and they will stay there. But the plan for the expansion of Gladstone, to make Gladstone a low emitter and to make Gladstone world leading, is gone. That's what we're going to do. We're going to see the slow de-industrialisation of Australia because of this. As we heard my great friend and colleague Senator McDonald say, money is transportable. It can go where it wants. It goes to the return. It doesn't care where it goes. All we will end up exporting are our jobs and our pollution. When we go through all the things we want as part of this bill, no-one's talking about reducing demand or reducing our lifestyle. All we will do is reduce the things we are reliant upon. A very good lesson I learnt the other day is that sovereignty is the ability to make your own decisions based on safety. This bill signs away our sovereignty. We won't be producing things, we won't be making things and we won't be doing these things, so we'll become reliant on others—not friendshoring, not onshoring; we'll be offshoring.

In relation to how we go forward and what this bill does, I'll quote the Prime Minister, who promised during the election 'a future made in Australia'. He said we 'will rebuild our proud manufacturing industry', and build a future made right here in Australia. That's what he wanted to do. We've debated a bill here today about the National Reconstruction Fund, and we want to do more manufacturing, but this bill takes away from that. We are taking with one hand and giving with another. It is a waste of taxpayers' funds. It doesn't make it efficient.
An honourable senator: What are you talking about?

Senator CADELL: I don't know! What we should really want to do is be consistent across our policies, and this is not doing that. This is not something that promotes manufacturing; it is something that takes jobs away. We don't know what it is. It is a policy bubble. It is a thought bubble from a government that had an idea that wasn't that bad—let's clean up our economy—but we're taking a baseball bat to jobs and a baseball bat to workers.

We can sit here and shout and talk across the chamber, but what this really is, is a step too far. We sit here, and what we want to do is create a better world. We heard Senator Faruqi talking about the 50 million displaced in Pakistan. Nothing will change because of this. We are offshoring to China the same pollution in a less efficient way. There will be more pollution. If you look at the calorific value of Australian coal, at 62,000 kilojoules, we'll burn dirtier coal in dirtier plants to produce the same thing. That's the worldwide solution on this. Australia and some Brazilian coal is the cleanest and most efficient in the world, with low sulphur. And what we will do is replace it with dirtier, worse coal. That's the sum total of this policy.

People have talked about all sorts of things. Senator Farrell today talked about manufacturing. He was talking about Holden closing and about Ford closing. I just want to say that we've seen this before. The last time the Labor government brought this up was when it was in power under Prime Minister Kevin Rudd, and the policies we passed in this place led to end of the automotive industry. On 5 February 2008, Mitsubishi was the first to jump ship, seeing the first thousand people lose their jobs in automotive plants. That shift away from manufacturing, from that point, has always had negative effects.
Senator Ciccone interjecting—

Senat
or CADELL: Mitsubishi—that's exactly what I was saying, Senator Ciccone; thank you for that. Mitsubishi was where it all started under Prime Minister Rudd. Without a strong manufacturing sector, we risk losing our ability to develop these new technologies and products that keep us at the forefront. Furthermore, this de-industrialisation will also have serious implications for our national security. Without a strong manufacturing sector, we will become increasingly dependent on other countries for all of our essential goods and services, leaving us vulnerable to supply chain disruptions and other risks.

What can we do to prevent this de-industrialisation? We are standing here and we are being shouted at for these things. We don't stand up and say this is bad for the sake of it. No-one here is saying we shouldn't go for a cleaner economy. What we are saying is: don't throw the baby out with the bathwater.
Honourable senators interjecting—
The PRESIDENT: Order! Senators, not only is it disorderly to call out across the chamber, but most of you are not even in your seats. Senator Cadell, please continue.

Senator CADELL: If we look at one specific thing, I want to talk about concrete. Concrete is one of those engineering marvels. Rocks, sand, cement, fly ash and water all mixed together give you something very hard and very durable. Nearly every footpath and every shared cycleway you walk or ride down is made of it. Every kerb, every stormwater drain, away from homes, and most pipes and culverts convey stormwater with concrete. Most dams use concrete. Many homes in suburbia have a concrete slab for a floor, and if not they use concrete products in their home. Maybe you don't own a house but live in a high-rise—that's concrete. Schools and hospitals are made of concrete. What about the engineering marvel the federal coalition funded—the Pacific Highway? There are millions of cubic metres of concrete on the Pacific Highway, funded by the previous government. Every road and tunnel is concrete. You want to cross the river? Concrete bridges.

Concrete is everywhere. The most consumed product in the world behind water is concrete. Cement Concrete & Aggregates Australia says that about 30 million cubic metres of concrete is produced in Australia a year. That's enough to fill the MCG to the brim 18 times. Not only is it a wonderful building project; it is green. It is recycling fly ash and slag that would otherwise be waste. It is an amazing product. But the concrete industry in Australia will die under this bill. We'll be exporting all our raw materials, we'll be importing fly ash, and we'll be putting lower amounts of fly ash into concrete, making it less durable. All of our infrastructure will last for a shorter period because we have worse concrete—it's that simple. The consequences of what you are doing won't be what you want them to be. Yes, there will be less emissions in the world—well done!—but there will be fewer jobs. People get up and say that, per capita, Australia has higher emissions than any other country in the world. By GDP, we do not. Many of our Pacific island partners, who don't have a high GDP and who sit there and have a crack at us, perform worse than us by GDP. We have high emissions per capita because we produce a lot; we bat above our average on so many things.

We aren't doing things overly badly but we should always try to do things better, and I'm sure there is somewhere between where we are and where this bill takes us where we could all be happy. We don't want to drive anyone back to the Stone Age because we have a country and a planet that we all want to protect. We on this side have people we want to protect. They are the people who live in our country—the people who live in our states and in our suburbs. This bill doesn't take enough account of that.

Sure, we can have a crack about the deal done with the Greens. If hypocrisy had a colour it would be green. These people sit here and say they want to look after housing, put in extra housing, but every Greens councillor across Australia votes against every DA. They say they want lower emissions from power, but they don't want nuclear, which would give us all the power we want with no emissions. They are not a party of solutions; they are a party of problems. They don't want to solve anything, because then they would be relevant.
Government senators interjecting—

Senator CADELL: The Greens are irrelevant to our problems, and you are empowering them. They are an entitled child that you are supporting. That's what is wrong with this. No matter what it is, there is a party in here, which you are doing deals with, that points out the problems but not the solutions. Now we are sitting here and empowering them on this. We're going down this path and there'll be no coal and there'll be no iron ore coming from Western Australia. In my home state, at the port of Newcastle, we've already seen the $200 million that was set aside to help diversify the port for containers disappear in a puff of Minister King magic. What do we give them?
Senator Ciccone interjecting—

Senator CADELL: We can't give them concrete—through you, Madam President, I will take that wonderful comment from Senator Ciccone. It would be great to give them concrete, but we can't even give them that. We are going to become, in the words of Paul Keating, the new banana republic. The problem is, once we make the bananas we won't have any way to ship them, because we won't have roads made out of concrete to take them there.

As we go forward, as we go to the next policy to be delivered by you guys, let's just have a conversation. I sat there in the NRF debate and was able to say I thought the bill had a lot of redeeming qualities. I didn't take the micky out of it just for recreation. It just didn't go far enough. But it was a conversation that we had, and I thanked Senator Ayres at the time for giving me some briefings on it. With this one I can't. I'm sure that some of you over there are also saying, 'Yes, this might be going too fast,' especially with what you've done with the Greens. Not just do we have a responsibility to our party; we have a responsibility to this nation more than anything else. And this isn't good policy. We will sit here and we'll be laughed at—
Senator Carol Brown interjecting—

Senator CADELL: Senator Brown—through you, Madam President—you'll love this; I can't wait for the interjections. We don't want to sit there in three or four years time and say, 'We were right, and now we've got to fix it.' Let's fix it now; let's get it fixed. The thing we least want is to be sitting here in four years time with an economy in trouble, with nothing being built, saying, 'We told you so.' We owe the country more than that.

Senator NAMPIJINPA PRICE (Northern Territory) (01:49): This morning I rise to speak on the Safeguard Mechanism (Crediting) Amendment Bill 2023 as a proud Territorian with a visceral connection to the land and, of course, the environment. I would argue that few people in Australia truly do care more about real action on protecting the environment than those of us who live in regional and remote parts of Australia. This country is full of natural wonders—some of the best in the world are right here in our backyard—and we're all truly blessed to call this great land home and say that we're all Australians.

Though all Australians can be proud of it, Northern Territorians in particular can be extra proud of the vast and diverse landscapes the Territory has to offer. Our territory, at 1.4 million square kilometres, is home to some of Australia's most iconic natural wonders. We have tropical rainforests, rugged mountains, wetlands and deserts—home to a rich variety of flora and fauna, many of which are found nowhere else on the planet. From the Kakadu National Park filled with mangrove swamps to floodplains, incredible birdlife, animals—including huge saltwater crocodiles—and breathtaking waterfalls, we in the Territory truly understand the importance of the environment and its protection.

For me, personally, from Uluru—a now iconic landmark with cultural significance to my people, the Warlpiri people, near my current home of Alice Springs in the south—all the way to the Tiwi Islands in the north, where I spent the earliest years of my life, the natural beauty of the Territory's environment is, in my opinion, unparalleled. It's a vast landscape I was lucky enough to live on and explore as a child. From the very beginning of my life I formed a connection with this country that will last my lifetime—as did so many other Australians. For many Australians, including many I am related to, the landscape is much more than something to appreciate and wonder at; it's their home. It is their culture. It is their livelihood. That is why I and countless others are so concerned with its protection, and it is why I'm glad to be part of a coalition that supports real action to make a real impact on protecting our natural spaces. In the Territory, we know we can work towards a cleaner future. We can work towards an environmentally sustainable future. We can work towards a future where our children and grandchildren can see the wonders that this country and, indeed, this planet have to offer, and appreciate them in full.

But I'm a realist. Though I love the land, I know any debate on this action must be done against the backdrop of the very real impact that decisions made in this building have on people in their day-to-day lives. This work must be done while accounting for the cost, financial and otherwise, our decisions will have on the everyday Australian who simply wants to put food on the table. We know that as people become more financially secure they begin to care more about their environment. Once the interior is taken care of, people look to the exterior. As Bjorn Lomborg, Danish author, environmentalist and social scientist, said:
Only when we get sufficiently rich can we afford the relative luxury of caring about the environment.

Lomborg believes that climate change is a problem we can solve without abandoning our economic prosperity and without abandoning billions of people to poverty, and that, 'Yes, we should act on climate change but we need to do it intelligently, and we need to do it in a way that is fair and just for everyone.' I agree, which is why, for me, it is important that any action on climate change be measured, be responsible and, at the bare minimum, not cause harm to Australians.

It is important to me that we enable the conditions for Australians to thrive, so that, secure in knowing they and their families have the essentials, they can turn their attention to protecting our rich natural environments—which is exactly what the coalition did for the near decade it was in power. While in power, the coalition met and exceeded our target commitments while improving the economy and making life easier for Australians. Take note: the coalition met and exceeded Kyoto climate targets, the coalition made a commitment to reduce our carbon footprint in a reasonable and achievable time frame and the coalition reduced Australia's climate emissions by 20 per cent on our 2005 level. Despite the climate fearmongering and anxiety-causing rhetoric of the green Left, the coalition was working and achieving real results while maintaining a strong economy that benefited Australians.

The coalition government had a plan to get Australia to net zero by 2050 without new taxes. The same can't be said for Labor. Labor's carbon tax, even if it is in the guise of a safeguard mechanism reform, is just another attempt to undo a balanced effort by the coalition and, in doing so, try to score cheap political points through Labor's typical virtue signalling and posturing. It will inevitably, I believe, lead to phrases like 'climate denier' being hurled at anyone who points out the very real impact their policies are having on Australians.

But the truth is that you can absolutely care about the environment and the potential impacts of climate change and still call bad policy bad policy. So let's call it what it is. This is bad policy. It's bad policy for the economy. It's bad policy for the environment. Most importantly, it's bad policy for the Australian people. This is a hidden tax on all Australians at a time when the cost of living is skyrocketing. It's at a time when energy prices are skyrocketing. It's at a time when many Australians aren't sure how they are going to afford the cost of filling up their car to be able to take the kids to school.

The worst part is that Labor can't provide evidence that this tax will even have any impact. In a move that shocked absolutely no-one, Labor failed to get Treasury to model the impact of its policy before pushing it on Australian industry. In a move that will shock absolutely no-one, Labor are trying to tax their way to prosperity. The Australian people deserve to know the impacts of policy. But, in their usual style, the Albanese Labor government are keeping the Australian people in the dark. Like with so many other policies and grand visions of their new Australia, they don't want to reveal the details. They just want to rush it through with good vibes and, 'How about how good we are all being?' They are going to rush it through with the promise of the warm and fuzzy feelings that accompany delusions of saving the planet with half-baked policy ideas.

It is a huge concern that I know I share with many other members in this chamber that we are being asked to vote on a bill without all the information we need, without all the information the Australian public need and, more egregiously, without all the information that the Australian public deserve. But, as I say, this Labor government doesn't care much for giving the Australian people the information they deserve. In many cases, as I think may be the case here, it is because they know that, should they give Australians all the information—all the facts and all the stats—the Australian public will say no. I know this is a position that many of my colleagues hold and, frankly, I think it is a position that some in the Labor Party must hold too. I think they share my concerns and those of my coalition colleagues. I think they are also worried about the lack of detail we are being given and the potential consequences it could have for Australians. I think many of them share my view that, while action to protect our environment is important, it is more important that we make sure that whatever action we take doesn't add to the struggles of Australians. But they won't speak; oh no, they're happy to toe the party line! So the Labor Party continues to push their agenda without properly informing the Australian public.

Before the election, many Australians warned that if you vote Labor you'll get the Greens. 'Vote Labor; get Greens!' But they were laughed off. They were told they didn't have to worry and that Labor wouldn't do the work of the Greens. We were told by Albo that he wouldn't be held accountable to the Greens and that he wouldn't capitulate to the Greens. But here we are, not 12 months later, and 'each-way Albo' has done it again. He has said one thing and done another. Labor promised that the coal sector would not be subject to harsh restrictions, but, hey, here we are! Labor promised that the gas sector would not be subject to harsh restrictions, but here we are. The PM told us that Australia deserves a leader who takes responsibility, but here we are. He has given in. He has capitulated. He has given Adam and his merry band their way again. And, in doing so, in capitulating to the Greens' demands on this mechanism reform, Labor has paved the way—

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT
( Senator Walsh ): Please resume your seat, Senator Nampijinpa Price. Senator McAllister?
Senator McAllister: Acting Deputy President, I just wanted to draw your attention to the standing orders that require us to use proper titles for people here and in the other place.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Yes. Senator Nampijinpa Price, please refer to Mr Bandt by his correct title.

Senator N
AMPIJINPA PRICE: Apologies; will do so—rookie mistake. Where was I? In doing so, in capitulating to the Greens' demands, he has paved the way not simply for another energy crisis but for an economic one too—because life hasn't been hard enough for Australians and the cost of living hasn't gone up enough for Australians; their energy bills went high enough already! Labor and the Greens are responsible for making our gas sector un-investable and worsening the gas supply crisis. Labor and the Greens will be responsible for driving up the cost of everyday goods and services because of this capitulation. Labor never tried to engage the coalition on this reform, instead turning to the Greens and giving them exactly what they wanted.

We have heard in this chamber the joy from Greens senators that they were able to contribute to that rising cost of living through their efforts in pushing for this bad policy. Labor, by capitulating to the Greens, continues to add pressure and struggle to Australians. Traditionally the party of the worker, at the last election, where the tables turned, the Labor Party became the party of the more-fortunate Australian. The Labor Party became the party of those who, once again, using the words of Bjorn Lomborg, can afford the relative luxury of caring for the environment. It is not a bad thing; indeed, it should be the goal of everyone in this chamber to work towards an Australia where we can all afford the relative luxury of caring about the environment. But hidden taxes like those that this bill will deliver are not the way to do it.

So today I suggest that we all turn our attention back to the worker—to the Australians who, out of necessity, are worried more about how they will heat their homes this winter than they are about climate change. Think about the impacts this bill will have on them. I suggest we turn our minds to the countless Aussies who will struggle with energy poverty throughout this year and years to come because the cost of the decisions we make here will become too much for them. I suggest that we return to the measured and balanced approach that the previous coalition government had worked to achieve. This reform adds a cost that will be passed on to consumers, to small businesses and to households already struggling. For that reason, I cannot support the Safeguard Mechanism (Crediting) Amendment Bill 2023.

talker.name: Walsh, Sen Jess (The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT)

p.span: Senator REYNOLDS (Western Australia) (02:04): I too rise to speak on the Safeguard Mechanism (Crediting) Amendment Bill 2023. If only this bill were just a harmless, virtue-signalling policy move by the Labor Party in this dirty shameful deal with the Greens. But it is economic vandalism of the worst possible kind. There is nothing safe about this bill, and, as colleagues have described, this is the green tail wagging the Labor dog. I was appalled to hear Senator Waters and other Green senators in this place tonight boasting about the secret deal they'd done and how smart and how clever they were: 'We are going to be absolutely destroying the Australian economy, destroying Australian jobs!' And why? Why are we here, after 2 am, pushing through this piece of legislation that is probably one of the most consequential pieces of legislation to impact the Australian people, and you are here feeling smart and smug and smiling and laughing about what you are knowingly about to do to the Australian people. And I just say, shame on you all, because you will come back in this place, 'Oh, we didn't realise it'd cause all these problems for the Australian people!' Well, if you do secret dirty deals, if you make sure the Senate can't scrutinise an important bill like this, if you haven't done the modelling, if you haven't been able to tell the truth to the Australian people about what this bill is going to do, well, shame on you.

This is like the cashless debit card, which you pushed through this place. You did a dirty deal with others in this Senate chamber, and we've heard this week the consequences on the lives of Australians of ideologically pushing something through that you haven't modelled, you haven't checked, you haven't consulted on. And you should be ashamed of yourselves. None of what you are about to do to our nation is remotely necessary, if you had done things properly. And you're saying that it's going to be protecting the economy. This new Labor tax is in the guise of a safeguard mechanism reform. However, it will do nothing for the environment, as you have heard from so many colleagues on this side of the chamber this evening. But the sad thing is that you don't have to kill our economy and kill jobs in this country to look after the environment.

I'd like to share with those in the chamber today what it actually looks like when you look after the economy, when you make good policy, when you consult, when you collaborate—not just in this place but also in the other place—when you model and you work out the best balance between our economy, jobs and the environment. Let me share with those in the chamber here—and if there is anybody listening at 2 am to this important debate—that you can look after jobs, you can keep down the cost of living, inflation and interest rates and keep unemployment low. You can do all that while still looking after the environment, and that's exactly what we did in government, and we reduced carbon.

If you want to know what good policy looks like, let me share some of these facts with you. In government, the coalition found the balance that needed to be made between reducing emissions to reach a cleaner future and also ensuring that Australia remains strong, prosperous and independent. While we were in office we grew the economy by 23 per cent in our nine years in office. We signed Australia on to achieving net zero by 2050, and we had a clear plan to do so, which was focused on technologies and not taxes. We absolutely did that. We on this side of the chamber reduced emissions by over 20 per cent on our 2005 base level, putting Australia on track to beat our Paris treaty commitments, which very few other nations were on track to do. That is lower than in any year under the previous Labor government.

Between 2005 and 2019 we on this side of the chamber, when we were on that side of the chamber, reduced Australia's emissions faster than Canada, Japan, New Zealand and the United States. We met and exceeded Australia's Kyoto targets by nearly 500 million tonnes. Our technology-driven, long-term emission reduction plan set out a creditable pathway to net zero by 2050—again, technologies, not taxes—and it was working. We did all of that on track to meet our carbon reduction plan while preserving our existing industries and creating more jobs here in Australia.

We established Australia as a leader in low-emission technologies, and we were positioning our regions here in Australia to prosper at the same time. This decade, the government that we led invested more than $22 billion in lower emission technologies, driving over $88 billion of total investment to reduce emissions while still growing the economy and creating jobs across Australia. Our approach to reducing emissions has been more effective than almost any other nation in the world to reduce emissions and keep growing our economy. Today, Australian's emissions are more than 100 million tonnes lower than when Labor said they would first be under Labor's previous carbon tax.

That's not all we did when we were in government. Australia's investment in renewable energy continued to break records, with renewables now making up almost one-third of our energy mix. That happened under a coalition government, not under your side. Australia had, under us, the world's highest uptake of roof solar, with one in four homes with rooftop solar panels. Across governments and the private sector, over $40 billion was invested under our government in renewable energy since 2017. In 2020 alone, under our government, Australia deployed more renewable energy than in the six years of the previous Labor government. We did it under our policy: technology, not taxes.

The coalition government invested in big projects, including Snowy 2.0, one of the largest pumped hydro projects in the Southern Hemisphere, and Tasmania's Battery of the Nation pumped hydro. The coalition government's green bank hit its $10 billion investment milestone, supporting more than 26,000 emission reduction and energy efficiency projects across Australia. We also made carefully considered and targeted investments in transition projects to support our renewables coming online, including investing $84 million in microgrids for our remote communities.

That is not all we did. That is not all we achieved. The coalition government led the way on waste and recycling. We wanted to see less waste going into our oceans and landfill and more reused and recycled. No longer are we exporting plastic, paper, tyres and glass waste. And that was not done under a Labor government; that was done under a coalition government. The coalition government's $280 million Recycling Modernisation Fund is driving a $1 billion transformation of the waste and recycling sector. Our plans significantly increased recycling rates here in the nation. They tackled plastic litter, improved battery recycling and will half food waste by 2030. Again, that was done under a coalition government, which kept our economy strong and Australians in jobs.

The Great Barrier Reef is a global tourist icon, a unique ecosystem and a wonder of the natural world. It contributes about $6.4 billion a year to the Australian economy and supports 64,000 jobs. We were committed to protecting it, and we did. In the coalition—
Honourable senators interjecting—
Senator REYNOLDS: You might hate to hear this, and I can hear you all laughing and cackling at this, but I'll tell you what, we are absolutely proud on this side of our achievements.
Honourable senators interjecting—
Senator REYNOLDS: You can talk down Australia, and you can laugh and cackle at 2.15 in the morning, but I tell you what—
Honourable senators interjecting—

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT
( Senator Walsh ): Senator Reynolds, resume your seat.
Government senators interjecting—
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Order! I know you don't want me to take breaks like this to call for order for obvious reasons, but I can barely hear Senator Reynolds, so order on my right.

Senator REYNOLDS: It is no wonder that those opposite don't want to hear the truth. They say constantly that we on this side don't care about the environment, that we don't care about climate change. Of course we do. I will happily repeat those statistics for you if you didn't hear them because you were too loud. We'll go back—
Government senators interjecting—

Sen
ator REYNOLDS: Let us have a look at our emissions reduction. Between 2005 and 2019 we reduced Australia's faster than Canada, Japan, the United States and New Zealand. We met and exceeded—we on this side of the chamber did—our Kyoto targets and we were on track to meet our Paris targets, where most other nations in this world were not. They talked about it. We were actually doing it here and we did not need to kill the economy through your new carbon taxes.

Not only were we doing a lot on recycling, waste, land care and protecting the Great Barrier Reef, we also protected our environment. We safeguarded our wildlife for future generations by investing $6 billion for threatened species, habitat restoration, marine conservation and environmental projects, including, for example—
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Senator Henderson on a point of order?

Senator Henderson: I apologise to Senator Reynolds for taking a point of order when she's giving such an excellent speech, but the interjections from senator opposite are completely unacceptable. Could you please ask them to desist. It's disorderly. Thank you very much.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT: It is difficult to hear Senator Reynolds. Please cease your interjections.
Senator REYNOLDS: It's not surprising that those opposite are trying to drown out what I'm saying, because this is the truth that they try to hide day in, day out.
Senator Polley interjecting—

Senator REYNOLDS: The fact is—sorry, if you didn't hear that, Senator Henderson; I will say it again—we invested $6 billion for threatened species, habitat restoration, marine conservation and environmental projects, including projects—for example, $74 million dedicated to koala recovery and conservation. This investment reinforced our support through the Threatened Species Strategy that has put vulnerable plants and animals on a far more sustainable path. Maintaining and expanding our protected areas on both land and sea was one of the best ways we could look after our natural environment, and we did. The coalition government expanded Indigenous protected areas covering more than 104 million hectares and declared two new marine protected areas in the Cocos (Keeling) Islands and Christmas Island. These marine parks are twice the size of the Great Barrier Reef and are home to thousands, if not millions, of native species. We also achieved more than 90,000 hectares of weed control over three million hectares of pest-animal control land. We invested over $1 billion in Landcare, which included land partnerships to protect our threatened species; restored wetlands; and improved soil health and firms. Landcare delivers practical solutions on the ground in partnership with local communities and environmental groups.

Yes, there is more, and I only have two more minutes. On bushfire recovery, the coalition government allocated $2 billion to the National Bushfire Recovery Fund, and $200 million was invested to help native wildlife and their habitats recover from the devastating impacts of the 2019-20 bushfires. The coalition government invested additional support to our national parks, including $233 million in upgrades to parks including Uluru, Kakadu, Christmas Island and Booderee national parks. Our coalition government protected our oceans by increasing our marine park coverage to cover around 45 per cent of our oceans. That was done by the coalition government, and not by the previous Labor government. We restored sea grasses, mangroves and salt marshes and supported marine life conservation while creating hundreds, if not thousands, of Indigenous employment jobs in those parts. We invested over $200 million in the Environment Restoration Fund to help improve the water quality of the Yarra, Swan, Canning, Torrens, Brisbane, Georges, Hawkesbury and Nepean rivers.

We demonstrated over nine years of government and through two years of a pandemic that you can be a good, responsible government; you can respect this parliament; you can look after the economy; you can look after the health of Australians; you can maintain jobs; you can keep downward pressure on the cost of living; you can keep control of inflation and interest rates; you can look after the environment; and you can also put the Australian economy on a sustainable carbon reduction strategy. But this— (Time expired)
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Senator Henderson?

Senator Henderson: Madam Acting Deputy President, I would ask if you could again please remind senators opposite that they are being most disorderly in the way they are continually rudely interjecting during Senator Reynolds's speech. I would ask you to bring them to order.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Thank you, Senator Henderson. I note that the chamber at present is relatively quiet.

talker.name: Walsh, Sen Jess (The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT)

p.span: Senator COLBECK (Tasmania) (02:20): I rise to make my contribution to the Safeguard Mechanism (Crediting) Amendment Bill 2023. I have to say I do agree with the point of order just raised by Senator Henderson. It is quite disappointing that Labor senators continue to interject and to reflect on coalition women in this place, after what we have seen over recent years and particularly over recent days. Perhaps some of them are a little tired and emotional on the other side.
Honourable senators interjecting—

Senator COLBECK: I note they are all very chatty and they want to talk over the coalition speakers, but not one of them is prepared to put their name on the speakers list and actually stand up and defend this terrible legislation. They're all there and very chatty. They want to reflect on colleagues across the chamber, which I find a bit odd in this environment where we have just had a review of behaviour in the parliament. They come in here and are completely disorderly. The disrespect the chair. They are not prepared to comply with the chair's directions with respect to orderly behaviour.

It really is quite a Sliding Doors moment we are seeing here today. We spent most of the first part of the day debating a piece of legislation that the government said was designed to promote manufacturing in this country. We heard all day from the minister at the table that this was about putting downward pressure on energy prices, promoting manufacturing in this country and reviving manufacturing in this country, if I recall what the minister at the table was saying correctly—and I think I do. I don't think I am verballing you; you were very persistent in your comments, Senator Farrell, even though you're not in your seat and are interjecting in a disorderly manner. You were very determined to continue to put the fact across to the chamber that the government's policies were about reducing energy costs. That was a very persistent point that was made.

But then we moved on to this piece of legislation. It's almost like we have been in two parallel universes. We spent the morning talking about building the manufacturing sector in this country, and then we come to a piece of legislation that will increase energy prices. We moved to a piece of legislation that will actually increase energy prices; diametrically opposed to what was being said in the debate this morning. A real Sliding Doors moment that we are seeing here in the parliament today.

We don't know the full details of this legislation yet because the government hasn't tabled its amendments to the legislation based on its deal with the Greens. We know—I have experienced it plenty in my time in politics, but I also know from living in Tasmania—how bad a Labor-Greens government is, particularly when they are doing Labor-Greens deals. Senator Chandler mentioned earlier in the day that when we had a Labor-Greens government in the four years in the lead-up to the 2014 state election in Tasmania, it was devastating for the Tasmania economy. It was only the election of the Hodgman Liberal government in Tasmania that turned the Tasmanian economy around. We now lead a whole series of indicators nationally for our economic performance. People are coming back. The economy's growing. Economic confidence remains high. That's what you have when you have good economic policy.

I think that's the key point we should be reinforcing, in contrast with the two pieces of legislation that we talked about today. If you have good economic policy, your economy will be strong, industry will grow and manufacturing will grow, as it did by a significant amount over the last three years of the coalition government because of our modern manufacturing policy, which Labor has dumped in favour of the legislation that was passed today. Quite frankly, I don't think this legislation will have any real effect in growing manufacturing. Then, this evening and this morning, we have this piece of legislation that will put prices up. It will damage our economy. It will damage our businesses. How do we know that it will damage our economy and damage our businesses? Because they said so. Because they told us. They told us through the committee process.

I'll start with the cement industry. We heard earlier from Senator Scarr, from the cement industry's submission to the Senate inquiry, how the technology that's required to meet the requirements of this bill doesn't exist.
