It won't exist for 10 to 15 years. So what will that industry do? It will move towards an import industry. During my time here but also, prior to coming into politics, my time in the construction industry, I've seen the issues that we've had with imported products: steel from China, for example, and occasionally cement from China. The high-quality, high-standard cement that's manufactured in this country goes into all our buildings—including this wonderful building—and our homes. I don't want to see those standards threatened by imported product. I don't want to see our jobs exported to China. I don't want to see that happening.

It's not just about those that are working directly for Cement Australia, which is 20 minutes south of where I live, at a place called Railton in north-west Tasmania. It is about the plant workers, but it's also about the maintenance workers. There's a railway that brings the cement from Railton to Devonport, to the silos there. There are the port workers that support two ships. Two of the 14 ships that are registered on the Australian coastline service the cement industry out of the north-west coast of Tasmania, taking that cement to the rest of the market. If that capacity goes, if there's no need for cement from Australia, there will be fewer ships on the Australian coastline. There will be fewer Australian maritime workers, fewer Australian railway workers and fewer vessels on the coastline, and what will happen? The emissions will be offshored and the jobs will be offshored.

We've heard from the other side, through their interjections on a number of occasions, that this is our policy. It's not our policy. They're taking a program that we put in place and turning it into a tax policy. That's what they're doing with this measure. They're increasing taxation and they're increasing costs on business. Their deal with the Greens makes it worse. That's been demonstrated again by comments over the last 24 hours or so that indicate what the real issues might be, particularly for the energy sector. What did the energy sector say? Only yesterday, off the back of the Greens announcement, the energy producers said Labor's '11th-hour safeguard mechanism shake-up' provides 'concern the changes would damage prosperity and make it harder and more expensive to reduce emissions'. So what does that mean? That means that it potentially would be harder to reduce emissions, which is what the government say is the whole intent of this legislation, and that it would cost more, which means higher energy costs.

This is a direct contradiction to what we heard this morning when we were debating the legislation in relation to building the manufacturing sector, because we know that, when it comes to manufacturing and any business or industry in Australia, the fundamentals are the fundamentals. Energy costs are one of the fundamentals to a competitive manufacturing and industry sector in this country. Sensible labour costs are fundamental to that, and we've already seen the Labor Party take the industrial relations framework back to what it was prior to Keating and Hawke. They continue to say they're doing one thing, yet all the time they're doing something else. They promise to slow our energy prices; they're delivering higher energy prices.

The commentary from industry continues to reinforce that. On Monday, there was an $18.7 billion deal to take over Origin Energy. What did R Blair Thomas, chief executive of the private equity business that took over that business, say? He said that 'government's moves to control energy prices is a "mistake" that would backfire and drive up prices for consumers, putting the whole energy transition at risk if public support for decarbonisation wanes'. Their own actions, through this legislation and particularly through the deal with the Greens, are putting their whole strategy at risk. They promised Australians lower energy prices; they are clearly delivering higher energy prices. It's a broken promise—we've talked about that plenty of times in this chamber—but it has the other effect of actually cutting the value of the Origin gas business. So they are diminishing the value of business in this country.

A number of my colleagues have said, quite rightly, how fluid investment is. Investment will flow to the place where it can get the best return and the best value, but that's not what we're seeing with today's legislation and the global investment market. Again, we had a conversation this morning about attracting more investment, and we heard during question time about the desire to attract more investment to this country—it's important that we do. But the government, in the decisions that they are making and the legislation that they are bringing to this parliament, are acting in a directly opposite way to what their stated intentions are.

They say one thing; they do another. They promise lower energy prices; they deliver higher energy prices. They promise more gas; they effectively place a cap on the gas market with the mechanisms that they're putting in place through this legislation. How do we know that? Because the Greens are out there boasting about it. There is nothing worse for this country—I can tell you; I've seen it in my home state of Tasmania—than a deal between Labor and the Greens. It means bad news.

I'll finish with the forest industry. I was at the forestry dinner just before Christmas, when the Prime Minister promised the forest industry that he would look after them. Of course, in two pieces of legislation today, we've seen them excluded by the Labor Party based on the party's deals with the Greens. The Greens will tell you that they want to move to a plantation based sector. There is a significant plantation based sector in this country, and it's extremely important, but the prejudice against native forestry, I have to say, is completely unfounded. It doesn't matter on which value you look at the native forest industry; it's better for the environment than the plantation sector. It's better for biodiversity, better for water quality—it uses no chemicals—and better for carbon storage. So, on any value you look at in relation to the forest industry—if you genuinely look at the science and not some of the hocus-pocus that comes out of the ANU here in Canberra—the native forest sector is better than the plantation sector, which is where the government is trying to drive the industry at the moment.

The plantation industry is extremely important, but you don't get high-quality furniture-grade timber out of the plantation sector. You don't get the special species that we grow in Tasmania out of the plantation sector in Western Australia, New South Wales and Victoria. The best quality timber is slowly grown timber with some age. That's best produced by a well managed native forest sector, which we have in this country. It's the best in the world. It's sustainable, harvesting less than 0.06 per cent of its available area every year. It's highly sustainable. So for a whole range of reasons this is bad policy; it's bad legislation; and, worse, because it is done through a deal with the Greens, it should not be supported.

Senator HENDERSON (Victoria) (02:35): I rise to speak on the Safeguard Mechanism (Crediting) Amendment Bill 2023. I regret to say, like my colleagues in this debate tonight, as I rise at nearly 20 to three in the morning, in this so-called family friendly parliament that Labor promised—this, of course, is another broken promise—that this is a bill that, if passed, will destroy our competitive advantage, will drive jobs offshore, will destroy investment confidence and will bring this country to its knees. This is a bill which demonstrates that Labor and the Greens, in this dirty, rotten deal, could not care less about the average Australian. The average Australian has been hit so hard with the skyrocketing cost of living under Labor, and is battling to pay the bills to put food on the table, to fill the car with petrol and to keep the heater on.

This is a bill which shows all Australians that Labor is all about slogans and not about substance. I, like some of my colleagues in this debate tonight, am also convinced that there are some Labor members or senators who don't believe in this bill, because they know the damage that this does to manufacturing, to our important industries, to the construction sector and to jobs, particularly blue-collar jobs. History is going to judge this Labor-Greens dirty deal as a very bad deal for our nation, just as I believe this Albanese Labor-Greens coalition will be judged as a very bad government for this nation. Particularly for the people of Aston, this is ricocheting every single day. The people of Australia will never forget the price that they pay under Labor; the price of broken promises on interest rates, inflation, wages, mortgages and power prices. Let us not forget that Labor, when in opposition, promised on 97 separate occasions that it would reduce Australians' power bills by, on average, $275 a year. What a laughing-stock! What a joke! There are broken promises on superannuation, franking credits and even the schools funding increase, which was promised but has now been delayed, much to the disgust of the Australian Education Union. I say to the people of Australia: you will always pay more under Labor. Do not risk Labor. I say to the people of Aston: look at this basket case of a government. Look what this government is trying to do now.

It is such a disgrace that we are talking about amendments to this bill that senators opposite do not have the courage to present to this chamber. What is going on? Why can't we see these amendments? The Greens were over there earlier in the night boasting about how their amendments are going to stop half the gas and coal projects in this country. They think it's wonderful, as they bring this country to its knees, in partnership with the Albanese Labor government. This is a disgrace. Labor and the Greens have done a deal. We are here at 20 to three in the morning and we do not have access to the amendments which form part of the proposed legislation before the Senate. What is going on that Labor will not allow us to scrutinise these amendments, will not allow us to debate them, will not be transparent? Where is Labor's integrity? Where is Labor's accountability? Where is the scrutiny? And where are the amendments?

In capitulating to the Greens' demands on the safeguard mechanism reforms—and we know they have because the Greens have been boasting about it here and in their press conferences, but Labor senators haven't had the courage to hand over their amendments, which is extraordinary; I've never seen anything like it before—Labor have sowed the seeds for not only the next energy crisis but the next economic crisis, one that will far exceed the current crisis in severity. The Labor-Greens deal is a hard cap on economic growth. The Labor-Greens deal is a hard cap on new industries. It is a hard cap on jobs. This is deindustrialisation, not decarbonisation. This is what the experts have warned the government about.

Labor's capitulation could put to an end new mines of any kind, including those for new critical minerals that will be needed for renewable technology development across the globe. That is extraordinary. We are a resource-rich nation. Critical minerals are critical to our future. The mining industry is now just existing in this country, with its back to the wall, with a government that clearly has no interest in seeing a future of mining and resources in this country. This is going to do irreparable damage to the energy market and penalise consumers. And let's not make any mistake; this is a jobs-destroying carbon tax. As the Australian reports on the front page this morning, online, this Labor government has been caught out deceiving, manipulating and not telling the truth about what this will do. Whitehaven, New Hope, Bowen Coking Coal and Peabody Australia have all condemned Australia's eleventh hour safeguard mechanism dirty deal with the Greens. They are concerned it will make it harder and more expensive to reduce emissions. This is climate policy gone mad. Gas producers have warned the Prime Minister that this so-called climate policy, which forces 215 emitters—or 212; I may stand corrected on that—to slash emissions by nearly five per cent each year until 2030, presents such a sovereign risk that it creates a real risk to Australia's energy security, including for vital international partners such as Japan.

As a senator for Victoria, I want to have a look at what this safeguard mechanism will do in Victoria to some of the companies that are being targeted. The first one, and one that I spoke about this morning in my speech on the National Reconstruction Fund—another reckless policy—is Viva Energy's Geelong refinery, one of the top emitters that have been targeted by this policy. Australian Gas Networks; AusNet; Virgin and Qantas, our two major airlines; Oceania Glass in Dandenong; Esso in the Gippsland Basin; Beach Energy in Lang Lang in south-west Victoria; Liberty OneSteel at Laverton; Mobil's Altona refinery; the Opal Australia Paper mill at Maryvale; Alcoa aluminium in Portland; Qenos' Altona manufacturing; Melbourne Water, because of the emissions when it comes to treatment of sewage; TT-Line; V/Line; CSL Australia, a global biotech powerhouse; BlueScope Steel in Westernport—these are some of the companies on the hit list in Victoria which will be badly hurt by this obscene policy.

I want to dwell on Viva Energy's Geelong refinery. This is a refinery that we backed to the hilt when we were in government, through measures such as our fuel security package, which ensured that Viva was prepared for any emergency. We increased our onshore diesel stock holdings and locked in jobs of our fuel-dependent industries such as our truckies, our farmers, our miners and our tradies. We invested, through ARENA, some $22 million for the country's first hydrogen refuelling facility. We've backed Viva every step of the way, including many of the 700 workers, most of whom are covered by the Australian Workers Union. This is a refinery which is critical for Victoria's and Australia's energy security. It supplies over 50 per cent of Victoria's and 10 per cent of Australia's fuel. It can process up to 120,000 barrels a day. It manufactures petrol, diesel, LPG, jet fuel, Avgas, bitumen, specialty solvents and low-aromatic fuel to support the federal government's petrol-sniffing prevention program. It now wants to build a gas import terminal which is capable of importing half of Victoria's gas at a time when we know there is a gas crisis in this country. The Daniel Andrews state government in Victoria refuses to give Viva the consent it requires, and the gas cap legislation passed by the Albanese government has created enormous uncertainty for Viva. While we backed Viva every step of the way, the Deputy Prime Minister—the missing-in-action member for Corio, and this is a very large employer in his electorate—has never once stood up and fought for Viva on these really important issues—keeping energy prices low, ensuring that they have industrial harmony and not the horrendous collective bargaining laws which are coming their way. Now, in relation to this horrendous policy, we've not heard a peep from the member for Corio.

Senator Reynolds gave a wonderful outline of our work in taking strong action on climate change. The safeguard mechanism was, under us, working well for years as a system to cap emissions while the economy grew. Now, Labor is changing the purpose of the scheme from one that stops emissions by encouraging businesses and backing technology to one that penalises businesses and increases taxes. The government is determined to see Australia tax its way to so-called prosperity, a plan that history shows will fail. This climate policy, along with Labor's other climate policies, will put a wrecking ball through the economy. Despite the strongest economy headwinds in decades and having already whacked businesses with higher energy prices, Labor now plans to hit them with a carbon tax. By pricing carbon dioxide at $75, Australia will have a price that is three times higher than the one set by the previous Labor government, and it is set to rise to $100 by 2030.

Labor is determined to make Australian businesses uncompetitive. The $75 carbon tax is significantly higher than the carbon price of eight of Australia's top 10 two-way trading partners, putting our industries at a significant disadvantage on the global stage. Australian businesses are at risk of closing down after being rendered uncompetitive, and thousands of jobs are at risk. This is a hidden tax which will hit everyone. As I say, this is absolutely dreadful policy. This constitutes a true betrayal of the Australian people, including blue-collar workers across this country. The government could not care less about manufacturing, about construction, about mining, about resources or about energy security. This bill must be rejected, and, if it passes, we will fight it. We will fight to reverse this terrible legislation every single day.

Senator ASKEW (Tasmania—Chief Opposition Whip in the Senate) (02:50): I rise today to contribute to the debate on the Safeguard Mechanisms (Crediting) Amendment Bill 2023. The coalition does not support this bill, surprisingly. That's not because we don't support action on climate change but because this bill is a dressed-up version of the carbon tax, which we all know is bad policy. A carbon tax is bad for the economy and bad for the environment. Those are two very good and realistic reasons for not supporting this bill. Australians know we need to balance our country's need to reduce emissions. We know we need to work towards a cleaner future for our children and grandchildren, but we also know we need a strong economy. We want Australia to stay strong, prosperous and independent, and we know this can be achieved if we balance both priorities carefully.

During the nine years that the coalition was in government, our economy grew by 23 per cent. While our economy was growing, we were also building our environmental credentials. During our term, Australia met and exceeded our Kyoto targets. We signed up to achieve net zero emissions by 2050, and we reduced our emissions by more than 20 per cent on the 2005 level. This put Australia well on track to beat our Paris treaty commitments. But, in just 10 months, the Albanese Labor government has rejected the coalition's balanced approach to the economy and environment, and now Australian households and businesses are paying the price. This bill is a ruse. Labor is using a safeguard mechanism and calling it reform, when it will really commit Australia to a carbon tax we've already rejected. Questions at the recent Senate estimates hearings show the government has not assessed the impacts of this policy. A major reform, like what is proposed here, needs consultation and should be explained so Australians know its impact before being committed to policy.

Labor claims that industry supports this reform, but many of the industries covered by the safeguard mechanism have expressed concerns about it. Just yesterday, the chief executive of the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, Andrew McKellar, asked the government for assurances for businesses that energy affordability and supply have not been compromised by the deal Labor brokered with the Greens to get this bill through. Mr McKellar added that business remains concerned about access to affordable and reliable energy supply. Ai Group chief executive, Innes Willox, said the changes proposed in this bill will need further scrutiny. The Minerals Council of Australia's Tania Constable said:

We want to make sure there are no project closures. We want to make sure that we're retaining jobs for Australians and jobs in the regions. And we don't see projects going offshore to places like Indonesia and Russia without any net benefit to Australians.

This bill has been rushed, and Labor is trying to push it through in this last sitting week before the budget. But we need a measured approach when we're talking about factors as important as our economy and our environment.

The safeguard mechanism as we know it has been working well for years, operating as a system to cap emissions while our economy grew. However, Labor now wants to change the scheme from one that stops emissions through encouraging businesses to cut their emissions to one that penalises businesses through imposing a carbon a tax. The coalition had already mapped out a plan to achieve net zero by 2050 without imposing any new taxes. We supported a carbon trading scheme that rewarded businesses who voluntarily reduced their emissions. Instead of imposing the big stick approach, our method incentivised businesses to transition to net zero. Australians don't need another tax. This climate policy destroys the hard work we've put in to build the economy, at a time when we're already feeling the pinch from cost-of-living pressures. Labor is pricing carbon dioxide at $75 per tonne, a price three times higher than what was set by the previous Labor government, which the public rejected at the time. Worse still, that price is set to rise to $100 per tonne by 2030, less than seven years away. This decision-making will have severe impacts on Australian businesses and make them uncompetitive as they struggle to operate against international rivals. The proposed $75 per tonne carbon tax is significantly higher than the carbon price set by eight out of Australia's top 10 two-way trading partners, putting our industries at a disadvantage.

Many of our international competitors and trading partners in key industries like alumina, cement, copper, coal, gas and iron ore don't have any national carbon pricing schemes at all. Our exporters will struggle against rivals offering the same products at lower prices, which not only reduces profits from exports but means less investment in Australia and fewer jobs. Labor is risking the closure of these businesses due to its uncompetitive policies. For a government that is talking big about making things here, it is working hard to ensure manufacturing is taken offshore through this policy. And then we'll be forced to import products we used to make here as well as deal with the increased emissions to ship the products back.

Businesses and Australian households are already battling to meet the rising cost of energy, with Labor's broken promise of a $275 cut to power bills. And now the cost from this carbon tax will be passed on to them too. In addition, this carbon tax will lead to higher building costs when we're in a housing affordability crisis, higher fuel costs when we're already paying more to drive our cars, and higher transport costs when we're already seeing supply chain issues and difficulty sourcing essential items like food.

We all want action on climate change to ensure we don't keep experiencing the floods and bushfires that have ravaged our country, but we do not want action that is going to put increased financial pressure on Australians, who are already struggling to make ends meet. The coalition does not support this bill or endorse the government's dirty deal with the Greens to force it through.

Senator McGRATH (Queensland) (02:57): Before I commence—with the indulgence of the chamber—a very good friend of mine is running the Ulster Way at the moment and is running 1,000 kilometres over 15 days. He is up to day 4, and I'm sure we all wish him the best of luck. He's raising money for parkrun UK. Gav, everybody here in the chamber—including the Labor Party, the Liberal Party and the National Party—wishes you the best.

I am here to talk about the Safeguard Mechanism (Crediting) Amendment Bill 2023. It is about carbon tax 2.0. It's like one of those bad Hollywood sequels that are never as good as the first movie. This carbon tax is bigger and uglier, and it's going to hurt you. It's going to really, really hurt you. Seriously, the coalition understands the importance of addressing climate change. In the previous government we knew we had to work to ensure that we would reduce emissions so that children, grandchildren and future generations would be safe and prosperous without the lights going out.

The trouble with the new government we have here in Australia—the Labor-Green government with the dirty, dodgy deals they do in the dark—is that the Greens are not just the tail wagging the dog. They've picked the dog up and, quite frankly, have taken it to the pound and given it away. That's how the Greens are treating the Labor Party. It is quite rude. The Liberals and Nationals sometimes have what we call 'creative tension' in our coalition, but we respect each other. It is quite clear that the Greens don't respect the Labor Party, because the Greens are claiming this bill is all their bill.
Senator Henderson: Where are the amendments?

Senator McGRATH: Thank you, Senator Henderson. Where are the amendments? I don't know if they could be in a drawer here—there's Minties there—or under this folder here. We don't know where these amendments are. And this is a tragedy. This chamber is here to ensure that the executive is held to account, but what happens when the Labor Party and the Greens in their coalition get together and do their dirty deals? It is really disappointing but not surprising that the Greens have been dancing and stomping and trolloping all over Australian businesses and those people who work in Australian businesses—the glee and the sheer happiness from that side of this chamber that they were going to stop businesses from operating. You just think: 'What planet are you on?' It's clearly not on planet earth.
I'd like to commend the Greens senators in the chamber tonight. They are making an excellent contribution to this debate! Quite frankly, we need more senators like this!
Opposition senators interjecting—

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT
( Senator Polley ): Senator McGrath, would you take your seat please. Considering that those on my left made a point of raising issues around interjections, I would say to them that it is disorderly to interject. You might feel like cheering, but we are in the Senate chamber. Senator McGrath, I look forward to the rest of your contribution.

Senator McGRATH: Thank you, Acting Deputy President. There's never been a truer thing that you've said, actually! To the many people who are listening—all three of them; and hopefully Peter Wilson is one of them, on his tractor doing some late harvesting up on the downs—it is important that there is some accountability here. What is missing—and we should be aware of this, for those who are listening and the poor people at Hansard who are going to have to transcribe my words—is: why are we here at three o'clock this morning? It's not a rhetorical or philosophical question, where we can all hold hands and sing 'Kumbaya'. Why are we here at three o'clock on a Wednesday morning when, if you look at the timekeepers, Senator Canavan spoke at about 11:45 pm and Senator Cadell spoke at about 1:30 am. Why are we here? Because Labor and the Greens, as part of their dirty deal done in the dark, are like a mad bunch of French republicans from the 18th century and they've got the guillotine out and they've been guillotining left, right and centre. Indeed, today we witnessed them actually guillotining the guillotine. Pre-revolutionary France, when the revolution was happening, would have been saying: 'Goodness gracious me!' They would have loved having you there with your use of the guillotine.

What has happened is that the opposition, the official opposition, has been denied the opportunity to adequately and properly test this legislation through the processes of this parliament. What is interesting is that it's not just in relation to this bill. Only on Monday night, Senator Roberts moved a motion in relation to a referral to a Senate committee, and so did my good colleague Senator O'Sullivan. What did the Labor ministers at the table do? They moved the guillotine. They moved that the question be put. It stopped the ability of senators in this chamber to speak to that particular debate.

Increasingly in this chamber we're seeing that we've got this power bloc who are using their power to push and to dominate and to restrict the right of this chamber to adequately test legislation. That's why we're here at four past three in the morning making our second reading contributions. This is the Labor Party who talked about family friendly hours. If this is family friendly, I'd hate to see your families, because, quite frankly, this is not family friendly. And we're going to sit late tomorrow night because this is another broken promise from the Labor Party. They promised, 'We'll have family friendly hours.' Err, no, we're not. We're not going to have family friendly hours.

As to, 'We're going to have kinder, gentler politics,' it was very noticeable before, by the way, Labor senators, that when Senator Reynolds was speaking the interjections were incredibly disorderly. But when Senator Colbeck got up to speak, you went very silent. It was very, very noticeable that you were targeting Senator Reynolds. But when Senator Colbeck got up you all went very, very quiet. It's very interesting how you target certain female coalition senators. We know what you're up to. You did it when we were on that side of the chamber, and now you're doing it again. You're focusing—that is shameful.
Honourable senators interjecting—
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Order! Senator McGrath, can you resume your seat. Thank you. You may return to your speech.

Senator McGRATH: If I could my place in the speech, that would be brilliant. I was talking about the fact that Labor like to target Senator Reynolds, which is disappointing, but also of the dirty deal done with the esteemed members of the Greens party who are contributing to this debate at the moment. That is what is really sad about this, because you promised the Australian people that you would have transparency. You promised that you would be accountable. But guess what? You haven't been transparent, and you're not accountable. And guess what? You are breaking promises.

This bill is another example of one of your broken promises, because this bill will not keep the lights on in a range of businesses, and if their lights go out it means that Australia hurts. When Australia hurts it means that the people who sent me and the people on this side of the chamber here are going to hurt because of this bill. We know they're going to hurt because your broken promises. This is the Labor Party that promised 97 times before the last election that they would cut power bills by $275. That's not happening. Power bills are actually going up by more than $275. Power bills are going up by anywhere between 25 and 40 per cent, depending on where you live. This is modern Australia under the so-called caring, family friendly Labor government. They are not caring and they are not family friendly. Goodness me. Try and get them to say the figure of $275, or 275 or even 572. They will not say that figure in this chamber because they know that they lied before the last election when they made that commitment, because they are not going to deliver on that commitment.

We also know that when it comes to the stage 3 tax cuts—we know that this bill is actually carbon tax 2.0, and we know that Labor love taxes. The bigger the better—giant, throbbing taxes that come after you, taxes that wedgie you in the playground, drag you to the toilets and flush your head down the dunny. That's what this is about. It is a giant, throbbing tax that's going to hurt Australians. Carbon tax 2.0. It gets better—or worse, because we are here on behalf of the taxpayers of Australia on this side of the chamber—when it comes to the stage 3 tax cuts. We all know you're going to ditch them. You used such measly, weaselly words when we asked you questions about it in the Senate. We hear from ministers, 'It's our intention to do this,' or, 'We've got no intention to do that.' You're going to ditch them—another promise you've broken—because this government is a tricky government. It is a government that has been characterised by its ability to make grand-sounding promises and bring in bills with grand names, but in fact this government, at its heart, is about breaking promises and taxing Australians. That is wrong. We believe taxes should be cut because we believe that the money that Australians earn is better in their pockets rather than in your pockets, because, quite frankly, you will waste it. And that is wrong.

What we've got to consider when it comes to the Greens and when it comes to their approach to energy in this country—for example, in the last 24 hours in Queensland, 70 per cent of electricity was generated from black coal, five per cent from gas, 11 per cent from solar, two per cent from hydro and four per cent from wind. The deal that Labor have done with the Greens is terrifying. It's actually going to really hurt Australians. These are not partisan talking points here. The deal Labor have done with the Greens will hurt Queenslanders. Sadly, Labor senators are laughing at this because they think it's funny when people get power bills they can't afford. They think it's funny when people are pulling their kids out of sport because they can't afford their registration fees because of the cost-of-living crisis in the country. And your priorities are to bring in this bill. Your priorities are to waste the Senate's time on this bill instead of dealing with the cost-of-living crisis in this country. Yes, I'm going to be passionate about this and I will be partisan about this. We will hang this bill around your neck and we will remind you, Paul Keating-style, like a crown of thorns, every day until the next election that this bill—
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT: Senator McGrath, I will pull you up. You are to use former prime minsters' titles in your speech, no matter how passionate you are. I draw that to your attention.

Senator McGRATH: I refer to former prime minister Paul Keating, that prime minister who wrecked this country by bringing in the recession we had to have; that guy who the current Treasurer did his PhD on—oh, heaven help us! So yes, I'm passionate about the cost of living in Queensland. Families in Queensland are pulling their kids out of sport because they can't afford it, because of the cost-of-living crisis happening on your watch. And what we see from the Labor senators is laughter. It is shameful, that the Labor government thinks it's funny that families in this country are struggling to make ends meet.

I'm sorry, Acting Deputy President Polley. Labor have done a deal with the Greens. The Greens want to stop the coal being dug up, want to stop the gas being pumped out and don't want to build any hydropower stations in Queensland. So where is the power going to come from? Power bills are going up at the moment but, as a greater challenge: where will the power come from in the future? The deal you've done with the Greens means that Australia is actually turning its own electricity supply off. When families want to turn on their TV they won't be able to because there won't be any electricity coming out of that power switch. That is a tragedy. This bill is about short-term thinking and about doing the deal with the Greens, rather than being a bill that improves on the work that was done by the previous government.

As an opposition, we always want to work with the government where we can make legislation better. That is our role, and that is the role of this chamber. It is sad and unfortunate that the Labor Party in government have seen fit to do a secret deal with the Greens behind closed doors. You will reap what you've sown with that, because the Greens are not the friends of Australia. They're not the friends of those Australians who make this a better place. The Greens are only the friends of themselves, and you're in bed with them. So good luck.

talker.name: Polley, Sen Helen (The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT)

p.span: Senator McKENZIE (Victoria—Leader of the Nationals in the Senate) (03:12): I rise this evening, or this morning, to speak about the government's so called Safeguard Mechanism (Crediting) Amendment Bill 2023. I rise very proud, in particular, of the National Party senators who have risen throughout this debate, putting on the record the very real lived experience of the men and women in those communities that have sent them all to this place. That's because they come from the places that will bear the brunt and the negative impacts of this bill. Those opposite don't like to hear about the communities we represent. They don't want to know that what's popular in the cities is going to negatively impact those of us in the regions. Every one of the National Party senators made intelligent, thoughtful contributions born of lived experience, and they have done their job here in putting on the record tonight the impacts that this legislation will have on their people, on our industries and our communities. I'm very proud of them.

I say 'so-called safeguard', because, regrettably, there are no apparent safeguards in this bill for the parts of Australia that are most likely to be impacted by this Labor government's dirty deal with the Greens and their drive to reach an emissions reduction target of 43 per cent below 2005 levels by 2030. I refer to the explanatory notes attached to the bill, which cite the Nationally Determined Contribution commitment that Australia has made to global emissions reductions, and the Labor government's updated NDC under article 4 of the Paris Agreement to the UN. What is not mentioned in the update is that one of the first acts of this Labor government upon gaining power was a decision to strip out a commitment that our government made to measure the economic and social impact of our NDCs periodically, independently and rigorously. That was part of our nation's decision—to see, when we have made those ambitious targets, who is impacted, what the socioeconomic impacts are and therefore what the responsibility of the government in charge, as we head towards net zero, will be to those communities and those industries. The stripping out of this addition to Australia's NDC was done deliberately, secretively and, in my view, with a cynical disregard for the people who live outside our capital cities.

This bill will require Australia's 215 largest emitters to reduce their emissions by 4.9 per cent every year to 2030. Of the 215 facilities penalised, 84 per cent of them are in regional Australia, and 88 per cent are in sectors that are critical to our economic prosperity. It beggars belief—but not surprise. These are enterprises that support the agriculture, construction, manufacturing, transport, logistics and resources extraction sectors—enterprises which together underpin our nation's wealth, keep our GDP growing, help pay for our universal healthcare system, our world-class way of life and standard of living, our roads, our defence forces and our public education system. There was no mention in Mr Bowen's second reading speech of the regions—not one mention, despite 84 per cent of the impact being felt in the regions. But why are we in this chamber surprised? You don't care. You don't represent them. You actually couldn't give a damn about the impact on the most vulnerable communities in this nation as you strive to fulfil an urban-centred policy ambition.

Instead, we heard another fable: that this bill would result in the Australian electricity system becoming cheaper through the deployment of renewable energy. You have defied the laws of physics and tried to suspend the laws of economics since you have come to power. But, unfortunately, there will be a reckoning for this government and for the people of Australia because of this suspended reality that you try to weave. The lived reality of Australian families and businesses is that under your government power prices are going up, no matter how much Senator Farrell tried to talk about downward pressure with his hands in his contributions today. The fact is they're going up, up, up and up.

You cut the Regional Accelerator Program, which was modelled on similar support programs put in place in the EU to support regions during decarbonisation of the European economy. This was the first down payment to assist the most vulnerable communities during the move to net zero, but you cut that. That was one of your first decisions in your October budget. And here you are, penalising regional communities again.

This mechanism will cover industries such as steel, aluminium, manufacturing and transport and will include Woodside's North West Shelf gas project, Chevron's Gorgon gas project and Port Kembla steelworks. The mechanism includes Qantas, Virgin and Rex, at a time when tourism and aviation is just getting back on its feet and when airfares are already skyrocketing, particularly to our regional communities.

Guess what? Australia Post is captured in this mechanism. It is undergoing an existential challenge to its operation through technological change. How do we know what will drive Australia Post's future rationalisation? The minister was contemplating, earlier this evening, the conflation of two issues. Well, you've captured Australia Post. What are going to be the implications for Australia Post? Are they simultaneously going to stop delivering letters in an effort to reduce emissions? Are the posties going to take up scooters instead of vehicles? Seriously, what is the impact of your decisions? You don't want to talk about it. No-one on the other side of the chamber has talked about the impact of this. It is much broader than we've been led to believe.

Australian companies like BlueScope Steel have already conceded this bill impedes the viability of their manufacturing capability onshore. No-one's listening. Cooee over there. Construction industries like aluminium, steel and cement have few options for abatement yet are left to bear the brunt of financial burdens imposed under this government's wider emissions reform. The Cement Industry Federation in their submission to the Safeguard Mechanism Reforms consultation paper said, and I quote:
Around 70 per cent of scope 1 emissions arise from the calcination of limestone that is unlikely to be avoided or reduced with existing technology in the next decade.
A technology pathway exists for scope 1 (carbon capture use and storage) but will not be in place until at least 2035.

This is not fantasy football; these are facts from heavy industry that actually build this country and build our roads. You want to build houses? You want to construct cities? You can't do it without the cement industry, and they've got no mechanism for abatement until 2035. But you don't want to hear it. We are careering towards a crash of ideology and reality. In the transport industry, major rail haul operators like Aurizon and Pacific National will be targeted. Aurizon CEO Andrew Harding agrees these reforms have a structural flaw, and the risk is again the opposite of the intent of the bill. More freight will be pushed back onto road, off rail, as a result of this bill, pushing up the emissions per tonne of product moved.

A pattern is developing, with the government, of contradictory policies. On one hand it wants more affordable social housing and a renaissance in our manufacturing sector, and on the other it introduces measures that make raw materials more expensive and power more expensive and places imposts on industry that make them more unviable or invite companies to move offshore. On one hand it wants more sovereign capability, and on the other it's taking away our natural advantage of access to reliable and inexpensive power. In the end the cost of these reforms will be passed on to Australian households and therefore ultimately Australian workers.

This will hang around the Labor Party. It won't be the Greens that pay for this, Labor, because they don't represent the workers. I know you're having an internal fight about which unions are supporting which political party at the moment. It will not be the Greens, who represents the most affluent white-collar workers in the country; it will be the Labor Party who actually have their legacy as the party of the workers further trashed as we see jobs move offshore—the opposite of the intent with which you brought this bill to parliament, because of the deal you have done with the Australian Greens.

As companies scramble to find ways to reduce their emissions over coming years, households can expect higher fuel costs, higher energy costs, higher waste disposal costs, higher building costs, higher transport costs and higher costs for groceries and other goods they buy. This is absolutely the worst time for the government to introduce a bill such as this, in an inflationary period. Every single time this government has had an opportunity to make the right decision to put downward pressure on the cost of living, to put downward pressure on inflation, they've made the wrong call—every single time—and it will be Australian families, the most vulnerable in our communities and I argue regional Australians in the main who will pay for this ambivalence.

The government's clear intention is to phase out coal-fired power stations as quickly as possible but without the transition technology, especially gas, needed to supplement renewable projects to support the transition. You've been crippled by the Greens. It's insanity. No-one else in the world is doing this. It's like you all need to go back to year 8 and understand the laws of physics and economics. You are making decisions that defy both. Everyone in this chamber accepts moving to a net zero position and accepts Australia doing its role in that global task. But not until you've got a substitute, which is exactly what you're not doing. You're being held to ransom by the Australian Greens, and it will be Australian workers that pay.

Robert Gottiebsen, reporting in the Australian, quoted today's revelations from the CSIRO Chief Executive, Larry Marshall, who was speaking at the Australian Davos Connection leadership conference in Brisbane. This is not some right-wing radical; this is the CSIRO Chief Executive, and we have had enough of their reports quoted to us on this side of the chamber over the last number of years to back up any number of Labor and Green ideological requests. But I'm begging you to listen to the same CSIRO you've quoted back to us. He said, '… without gas in the mix of electricity sources, the target of zero emissions by 2050 would cause widespread power shortages'.

Samantha McCulloch, the Chief Executive of APPEA, states the safeguard mechanism changes strengthen the need to back carbon capture and storage, which you steadfastly refuse to do, even though the International Energy Agency has said the only way the globe gets to net zero is through the technologies of carbon capture, use and storage and nuclear. It's not the National Party saying that, it is the same international agencies and experts you quote back to us, but you're very selective about what you will listen to, to the Australian public's detriment, I fear. While the United States is supporting CCUS and Britain is also now investing in it, the Albanese government cut funding for carbon capture, usage and storage by $250 million in the October budget. In simple terms, the Albanese government is driving us to try and achieve a renewable nirvana with both hands tied behind her back.

Finally, it remains a leap of faith that the proposed offset and crediting system, which we know has been subject to manipulation and fraud, won't be manipulated. No one is commenting on that today, how it will somehow become gold standard. We on our side of the chamber fervently hope that this government's climate policies, of which this bill is a key part, will not destroy the very businesses it seeks to safeguard. We won't be supporting the bill.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT
( Senator Polley ): Can I just remind senators that your comments go through the chair.

talker.name: Polley, Sen Helen (The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT)

p.span: Senator DEAN SMITH (Western Australia) (03:27): Before I begin my contribution at this very late hour, I thought it important to acknowledge that the Senate is continuing to be supported by the Senate chamber staff and staff from the Department of the Senate. I wanted to acknowledge that because, as we deliberate, sometimes it's easy to think it is only about ourselves. But this chamber is still being supported at this very, very unfavourable hour.

As you've heard from coalition senators, the Safeguard Mechanism (Crediting) Amendment Bill 2023 is not going to be supported. I do want to associate myself with all of those remarks that were made last night and this morning by coalition senators. Because many people might be hearing it on the radio, they wouldn't be able to see what is happening in the chamber, and I think it's also important to note that earlier in the night we heard contributions from the Greens. In actual fact, the Greens have spoken more frequently on this bill than government senators have, and that is quite remarkable, given that it's a government bill that we're talking about tonight. As I said, the bill will not be supported by coalition senators, but, of course, it is important to acknowledge that the coalition is committed to transitioning to net zero emissions in a way that is responsible and protects the growth and prosperity of Australia. It's important to restate as well that the coalition exceeded Australia's Kyoto targets, signed Australia on to achieving net zero by 2050 and reduced emissions by over 20 per cent on our 2005 base level, putting Australia well on track to beat our Paris Treaty commitments. And, of course, under the coalition government emissions were reduced at a rate faster than some of our most important trading partners.

But at the core of this debate the Senate is being asked to embrace a reform initiative that has not been properly modelled. What does that mean? The effects of the legislation on the economy are unknown, and what we're saying is that, in that unknownness, there's a risk and you can only plan for the worst. The reform in this bill is unbalanced and it's immediate impacts will be felt disproportionately by regional communities across Australia. Other Australians will not escape the consequences. For them, this reform will be felt in further price increases for Australians, as the additional costs of delivering the required emissions reductions will be passed on the Australian households.

Critically, the Treasury confirmed at Senate estimates in February that modelling of the safeguard mechanism reforms had not considered broader economic impacts such as the impact on investment, the impact on jobs and the impact on prices. In addition to that, the Department of Climate Change, Energy, the Environment and Water also declined to provide senators with the economic modelling that was undertaken to fashion this initiative, and where information about costs has been available it has been revealing. The Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry confirmed business would pass their higher operating costs under this safeguard mechanism on to consumers. This is a very real cause of concern and alarm.

This is a bad idea happening at possibly the worst time for the Australian economy. At a time when Australia needs to be talking about the next tranche of reforms to protect our living standards and to protect this country from becoming poorer, what we're being dealt is a market intervention so severe that it will leave a lasting scar on many Australian industries. This bill will make Australian businesses less competitive when compared to our international competitors.

It's true that the previous coalition government had introduced a safeguard mechanism to limit the growth of emissions in the industrial sector by applying an emissions baseline on 215 of Australia's largest emitters. That reform delivered emissions benefits, but Labor's plans is not the same as the previous coalition government's plan. Claims that this safeguard mechanism policy mirrors the coalition's is designed to confuse and mislead. The new government safeguard mechanism will force facilities to reduce their emissions intensity by up to almost five per cent each year regardless of whether the technology exists for them to do so.

Without access and pathways to technology, there can be no pathway to decarbonisation of the Australian economy. Instead, many Australian businesses will have no option but to reduce production, move offshore or shut down entirely. That amounts to declining economic growth, lower levels of productivity and a fall in real income and living standards for every Australian. This so-called safeguard mechanism will be felt in the daily lives of many Australians. There will be higher building material costs in the middle of a housing affordability crisis, higher fuel costs in response to rising energy bills and higher transportation costs that will hit our supply chains. Australia's strength can easily be turned into a vulnerability when put in the hands of the ill-informed. As Australia is an open economy and an export-orientated trading nation, reforms such as this should be embarked upon with great care, a much deeper understanding of their consequences and a proper awareness of the drivers of our domestic and international competitiveness.

Concerns this reform may risk closing down Australia's cement, steel, aluminium, oil refining and mining industries have been met with disbelief by some people in the community and some senators in this chamber, but just this evening the first ripples of the economic repercussions of the so-called safeguard mechanism have been revealed. In this morning's papers, senators will be able to read how Australian coal companies have warned of a 'carbon tax by stealth', confirming that this safeguard mechanism will drive up energy prices, destroy jobs and kill foreign investment. Companies that employ thousands of Australians such as Whitehaven, New Hope, Bowen Coking Coal and Peabody Australia have all condemned this eleventh-hour—perhaps it's the 12th or 13th hour now—safeguard mechanism shake-up amid concerns the changes would damage prosperity and make it harder and more expensive to reduce emissions. These are the same companies that are the custodians of $15 billion worth of projects and that count billions of dollars in their investment pipelines.

These companies say the government's proposed amendments will make Australia uncompetitive, and that means making Australians poorer. The President of Peabody's Australian operations, Jamie Frankcombe, has said this legislation would:
… make the mining industry less competitive at a time when it's integral to providing the minerals and energy required for the energy transition.
He goes on to say:

The very real danger in setting aspirational emission reduction targets and imposing rigid rules to achieve them is that it will reduce our cost competitiveness, lead to potential job losses and hurt regional communities.

Glencore has said the reforms need to achieve emissions reductions without 'destroying the jobs and investments that are critical to our national economy'. The future owners of Origin Energy have said the government must better balance the need to reduce emissions while ensuring energy security. They've said:
If we don't get the balance right and we have the extreme volatility, like we saw in Europe last year, I think you're going to get very significant consumer backlash.
Consumer backlash—those are the two words that government senators should keep in mind.

At the last election, Labor did very well in Western Australia—and congratulations to them—but, to borrow Senator Scarr's term, Western Australians did not vote for this. When you look at some of the projects that are on the list of the 212 liable entities, they are projects that are household names in Western Australia. Let me just read some of them to you: Hamersley Iron projects at Hope Downs 1 mine, Hope Downs 4 mine, Brockman 4 mine and Brockman 2 mine; Pilbara rail operations; the Alinta Energy Transmission unit at Roy Hill; the Newmont Tanami operation; the Yilgarn iron ore project in Koolyanobbing; the BHP iron ore projects; the CSBP Limited Kwinana facility; the BP refinery at Kwinana; the Adbri Limited Dongara and Cockburn operations. These are projects that are going to suffer as a result of the safeguard mechanism.

Not 12 months ago, Western Australian voters put their trust in Patrick Gorman, the member for Perth; Tracey Roberts, the member for Pearce; Zaneta—whose surname escapes me—the member for Swan; and Sam Lim, the member for Tangney. Patrick Gorman, the member for Perth; Tracey Roberts, the member for Pearce; and Anne Aly, the member for Cowan, must now go and front their communities in suburbs like Clarkson, Merriwa, Morley and Bassendean and explain to Western Australian families who have benefited from well-paid jobs, flying up and out of the Pilbara region of our state, why it is that their jobs will soon be at risk—these are not my words; they are the words of industry itself—at a time when they're feeling mortgage pressure and rising cost-of-living pressures. A bad idea is being introduced at the worst possible time.

Why is it, then, that only one Labor senator, Senator Grogan, had the courage to come into the Senate and stand up and make a contribution on this bill? I have not heard one WA Labor senator come in here and say, 'This is a good idea for WA families,' or that they have not broken the trust of Western Australian voters, not yet 12 months since the election of the government. At the core of this is not just WA's prosperity and the prosperity of Western Australian families but the prosperity of the whole country. This is remarkable. It's a shame that more people are not watching the television, because the Labor senators have made little to no contribution to this debate. The Greens did all the speaking and they've gone home. You're left carrying the can. Wow, you have been really, really outdone by the Australian Greens. When we come back to this chamber in just a few hours time, I'm afraid to say, you should be very embarrassed because Western Australian voters will hold you accountable.

These are big projects that make Western Australia very successful and have given Western Australian families higher levels of income and higher standards of living than they would otherwise have had—and, in this so-called safeguard mechanism, you are putting that all at risk. And we have not yet had 12 months of this government. Wow. That is brave.

Senator RUSTON (South Australia—Manager of Opposition Business in the Senate) (03:41): I stand tonight, or this morning, to speak on the Safeguard Mechanism (Crediting) Amendment Bill 2023. I stand here at 3.42 in the morning because I think this is a really important piece of legislation. I wanted to make my contribution so that my voice could be on the record as opposing what has got to be one of the most farcical things that I've seen in a very long time. In doing so, I draw to the attention of those who may be listening now—or, more importantly, those that may consider my contribution at some other time—that the family-friendly situation that exists in this chamber is such that I had to wait until 3.42 before I could make my contribution because so many other people wanted to and because this government has not got the capacity to organise itself in an appropriate way so that we are able to have these debates in the chamber at a time that actually is family friendly. It does make somewhat of a joke of all the rhetoric we heard leading into the election about how we were going to be family friendly when, apparently, we're only family friendly when we want to be family friendly. When we don't want to be family friendly, we can be sitting here at four o'clock in the morning. I know that there are others who want to make contributions after me. It's very disappointing that that's the way we find ourselves today, but this is an important enough bill for us to stay out of bed until this hour of the morning to make sure that we put on the record the extraordinary concerns that we have about the impact that this bill is likely to have on Australia, on the Australian economy, on Australian businesses and, ultimately, on Australian families.

This is another broken promise. In the contribution before mine, Senator Smith made the comment that there are many senators out there who, when they get up this morning and read this morning's papers, will see that there is no hiding. It doesn't matter how much lipstick you stick on this pig; this is still a carbon tax. You can call it what you like but we have got a new carbon tax. I'm sure that should strike fear into the hearts of many Australians because we know what a carbon tax will do to our economy. It takes you back to those Julia Gillard moments when she said, 'There will be no carbon tax under the government that I lead.'

Mr Albanese went to the last election promising that he'd keep his hands off our resources sector. But tonight, after the dirty deal that's been done with the Greens, once again we see that this government cannot be trusted with what it says in the lead-up to an election. After it's been elected it'll do whatever it feels like. It will do whatever the green tail that's wagging the red dog will seek for it to do. So, tonight, we not only have a bad bill; we have a bad bill made worse by the deal that's been done with the Greens.

The real losers out of all of this are the Australian public, because, at the end of the day, when you put upward pressure through legislation, through regulation and through means like we've seen will be legislated through here in a minute—because we know the Greens have been bought—ultimately that cost is always passed through to the consumers. Right now, there has never been a worse time for us to be putting extra pressure on Australian families and Australian households as we see the cost of living spiralling across Australia.

The thing that should probably concern people more than anything else is, despite many attempts in this chamber to seek the government to provide the modelling that sits behind the impact of this decision on Australia, they have continuously refused to provide that information to the chamber. I've been around a while, and I've got to tell you that the first conclusion one always jumps to when somebody refuses to provide you with the evidence on which they are basing a decision is it usually means that their evidence is not particularly conducive to supporting what they are doing. We can only assume that the modelling that's been hidden by those opposite in relation to the impact of this decision on Australian businesses, the Australian economy and Australian families is the fact that it is actually showing that exactly what we think is likely to happen following this piece of legislation is exactly what is going to happen from this piece of legislation. That is, it's going to drive the cost of living up, it's going to drive prices up and it's going to make the Australian economy weaker.

In saying all that, I have to say I think that there would not be an Australian who wouldn't like to see a clean-energy future and that we take action to do our part in the world to make sure that we have a future for our children that is one where they live in a clean environment. But you can't just ideologically jump to a position of reducing carbon emissions in the manner that those opposite have already legislated with their 43 per cent without actually thinking about the significance and impact of the transition from where we are today to where we want to be into the future. I think if you ask any successful change manager anywhere in the world, 'What is the secret to success?' the secret to success of any change is the way you actually manage the transition to where you want to be. Right now, we have seen a lurch away from what I think our government did. That was to have a very sensible transition that allowed technology to drive the kinds of investments that we needed to make sure that we had an adoption of clean-energy technologies and clean-energy substances. This was to make sure that we had a clean-energy future that was built on the back of a prosperous economy and an economy that could rely on the fact that it wasn't going to get belted over the head by a tax but could be incentivised into providing that clean-energy future for our country.

The coalition met all its targets, yet somehow those opposite seek to demonise what has been achieved. We achieved every target that we have had before us. We met and exceeded Kyoto, we signed on to achieving net zero, we've reduced our emissions in excess of what we have said over our baselines and we've put Australia well on track to meet absolutely every target into the future. Yet those opposite somehow think that that fantastic track record, which saw us underpin a strong Australian economy, is somehow not good enough and, in pursuit of the ideology of some sort of green light into the future, it doesn't matter that you destroy the Australian economy going forward.

Senator Smith drew the chamber's attention to an article that's in the Australian this morning, and it could not be more damning of what the impact of this is going to be on one of Australia's absolute foundation sectors. It's the sector that has provided Australia with the wealth which has allowed us to be and our communities to be as strong as they have been for so long, and that's our resources sector.

This morning, our resources sector is basically condemning this government. The really sad thing is that we are probably going to have to wait to see the consequences of the actions of this legislation, the damage it's going to do on Australia, before those opposite will realise that what they've actually done is destroyed a very strong Australian economy, an Australian economy that had a reputation internationally as a great place to invest, a reputation as someone who put innovation at the head of what they did to try and make sure that our economy continued to be strong.

The problem is that what we have here is a piece of legislation that, basically, is about to render Australia's extraordinary competitiveness in the resources sector completely uncompetitive. I'm thinking about the names that sit on that list of the big emitters that will be hit by this carbon tax, the costs they will have to bear—which, clearly, they'll pass onto consumers—and what that will do to our economy. The thing that is really concerning is that, going into the election, we heard Mr Albanese saying that he would not be doing any deals with the Greens. He said they were going to be a government in their own right, and they were not going to fall over every time the Greens tried to force them into some of these ridiculously uncompromising and damaging situations. But it's: 'No, no, no! We can say one thing before the election, but after the election we'll do whatever it takes to make sure that we can get our promises through, no matter the cost to the economy.' Today we have seen exactly that.

This morning in the papers, we see many companies coming out and saying that what we've seen is a really bad bill. The bill that was originally introduced by Mr Bowen has been made worse by the deal that's been done with the Greens. They draw attention to the fact that 70 per cent of Japan's thermal coal imports come from Australia, so it exposes our really close friend Japan to extraordinary new material risks in terms of their energy supply. Did anybody think about that? In the midst of a global energy shortage, and considering the alternative technologies that we need to be able to pick up the difference from our 80 per cent reliance on primary energy derived from fossil fuels today, it seems extraordinary that you opposite would conceive, or even entertain, these sorts of concessions that the Greens are demanding of you.

The challenge then is that we're going to see Australian prices pushed up as a result of this particular piece of legislation. Actually, not only will we see prices pushed up but we will see Australian jobs lost, Australian jobs offshored, and we will see rural and regional communities once again bearing the brunt of the kinds of decisions that those opposite make. Whilst we will see the economic wrecking ball that this will put through our economy across the whole of Australia, it will once again be felt first and hardest in rural and regional Australia. It seems quite extraordinary.

And add to that the pollution trigger that we have now legislated through the deal with the Greens; we now have a situation where emissions need to be considered in absolutely every project for approval. Whilst that may not in itself sound that bad, can you imagine what it is going to do? It's going to slow down every single project, and it puts another sovereign risk inhibitor into everything that happens in Australia. Mr Bandt was out there last night claiming that the deal is going to stop about 116 coal and gas projects that are already in the pipeline. What kind of politician would come in here and say, 'We've just gone and stuck the proverbial spanner in the works for your primary energy source at the moment, so you'll no longer be able to get back to it'? At the same time, Mr Bowen's out there saying the safeguard mechanism won't damage investment or drive up prices. You can't have it both ways. Either Mr Bandt is telling the truth or Mr Bowen is telling the truth. The really sad thing is that it's Mr Bandt who's telling the truth, not Mr Bowen, because the sad reality is that these projects will be stopped. Our economy will be stopped. The damage will be felt by the Australian economy as a result of this.

The other thing is the fact that, whilst this particular legislation seeks to make Australia's credentials look the way those opposite want them to look, in effect all it does is push the problem somewhere else. What we will see is economic activity that would otherwise occur in Australia being offshored to overseas markets with no carbon policies, or with bad climate policies, and higher emissions intensity. I don't know how on earth those opposite can sit there, in good conscience, and say that it is okay to shove our problems in Australia onto other countries, countries that are less able to deal with them and that have high emissions themselves, in the process of trying to appease an election commitment to the Australian public. We have a double whammy here. We have Australian businesses being rendered uncompetitive and forced offshore and we have, in many instances, a doubling of emissions in the places where these projects will be undertaken. It is just extraordinary that those opposite would sacrifice Australian jobs, leading to a perverse outcome for the economy.

At the end of the day, those opposite will have put a policy in place that will worsen the impact on the environment. It will push emissions to a place where they are less likely to be controlled and managed and, in the process, destroy Australian jobs. It will put a wrecking ball through the Australian economy, forcing up costs for Australians at a time when they can least afford more cost-of-living pressures, and those opposite don't seem to care. As I said at the start of my contribution, any increase in price will always have to be paid for. The increase in price that we'll see from this absolutely ridiculous policy, which is about to be legislated in this place, is going to mean higher costs for Australian companies, higher costs for Australian families, higher costs for Australian individuals and, sadly, a higher cost for the Australian environment and the world environment.

Senator BIRMINGHAM (South Australia—Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (03:56): It's no secret that the politics of climate change have frustrated me over my 16 years in this place, bearing witness to debates here, around our country and around the world. Too often I have borne witness to extreme arguments, variously coming from all sides—arguments that are detached from the facts of science, detached from the facts of economics or ignorant of the realities of geopolitics. It's also no secret that I have pressed, publicly and privately, for my party to adopt a more positive position at times on matters of climate change and that I've been concerned about extreme perspectives that too often consider Australia in a vacuum, as if our actions alone can solve these issues or can isolate us from these challenges. The challenge of climate change necessitates a careful, analytical and fact-based assessment of the problem, the cause and the solutions available—a sober, fact-based approach. In these early hours of the morning, I hope to work through at least some of those issues and place on the record my thoughts about how we should view the problems, causes and solutions, in the context of Australia and relevant policies for Australia.

The problems and associated risks around climate change are well articulated, studied and published, even if they're not accepted by all. Most recently, the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change's Sixth assessment report assessed the impact of climate change on ecosystems, biodiversity and human systems, with differing impacts across regions, sectors and communities, and outlined how best to reduce adverse consequences for current and future generations. The IPCC report found that impacts are increasingly severe, interconnected and often irreversible. It assessed the vulnerability of human and natural systems and outlined the role of adaptation in reducing exposure and vulnerability to climate change. It looked at the levels of resilience and how to further build them, including through transformations and transitions in human and natural systems. The IPCC report found that there is a greater than 50 per cent likelihood that global warming will reach or exceed 1½ degrees in the near term, and it observed the risks of concurrent hazards, compounding effects and extreme events.

From an Australian domestic context, from the perspective of many of our Pacific island neighbours, in particular, and from the perspective of most of our global friends and partners, these are risks that we can and should take seriously. This, of course, is not new news. Indeed, looking back on past contributions in some of these debates, I saw that way back in 2009 I quoted Margaret Thatcher speaking at the Second World Climate Conference on 6 November 1990. It's a quote many others have used at different junctures. She said:
The danger of global warming is as yet unseen, but real enough for us to make changes and sacrifices, so that we do not live at the expense of future generations.
But, unlike 33 years ago when Thatcher spoke, we do know much more now. Not all the dangers remain unseen. We have made some breakthroughs but we need to make more.

Commitments under international climate change agreements, like the Kyoto agreement and the Paris Agreement, tend to be benchmarked off 2005 levels. I entered this place in 2007, and it's instructive to look at the changes in the global and domestic emissions landscape over the horizon of that last couple of decades since those time frames. Globally, the concentration of CO2 in the atmosphere had moved from its stable long-run base of an estimated 270 to 280 parts per million up to 384 parts per million by 2007, rising up to 419 parts per million in more recent estimates. This shift in atmospheric concentration has been driven by growth in annual CO2 emissions, climbing from around five to 10 billion tonnes per annum through the industrial revolution and global population explosion to reach an estimated 31½ billion tonnes by 2007. But since then we have seen the rate of global annual emissions rise even further, to a reported 37.1 billion tonnes in 2021.

This continued growth in annual emissions and atmospheric concentration fits the narrative of despair and emergency that we so often hear about. But what of our role and our contribution here in Australia? Australia's emissions inventory, as reported under the Paris Agreement, has gone from 646 million tonnes of CO2 equivalent emissions in 2007 down to 498 million tonnes in 2020. So, while global emissions have continued to rise, Australia has reduced our emissions by 20 per cent, even as our economy grew by 45 per cent. That means that our rate of emissions intensity has declined even faster than our nation's actual emissions. You wouldn't expect or appreciate this from much of the commentary, but they're important facts for us to bear in mind.

Australia's share of global emissions used to be put at around 1.4 per cent of global emissions, but is now estimated to be closer to 1.1 per cent. More than half of global emissions are attributed to just three countries: China, which now accounts for around 32 or 33 per cent; the United States at around 12 to 13 per cent; and India at around six to seven per cent. The rapid growth in emissions from China and, more recently, from India—and of course from many other smaller nations pursuing their own development agendas—is understandable. It is a function of their pursuit of higher living standards—higher living standards which we otherwise celebrate their achievement of. The reality is that Australia's per capita emissions remain significantly higher than these countries, who are still charting their development trajectory. If we are truly to combat climate change and truly to heed the messages of the most recent IPCC report, the test is not only for how we further reduce our emissions to meet our net zero commitment and to achieve ambitious interim targets which track towards it but also for how we best enable China, India and so many other smaller but economically ambitious nations to realise their development goals without them further worsening the global emissions challenge.

This is where low-cost transferable technology is essential. Australia, in our journey over the last 20 years in reducing our emissions and our emissions intensity, has seen remarkable transformation as part of that journey. One in four Australian homes now has rooftop solar panels, the highest rate of penetration by solar PV in the world. Years ago, the solar PV market was filled by huge subsidies—feed-in tariffs and government intervention. Today, it is largely fuelled by cost competitiveness. Commercial realities make household solar stack up for homes around Australia. Increasing cost competitiveness also saw some $35 billion invested into renewable energy in the period between 2017 and 2020, because the economics had increasingly switched in favour of those renewables as a source of generation.

To achieve global net zero by 2050 the International Energy Agency estimates that low emissions technologies including solar, including hydropower and including nuclear must grow from around 40 per cent of global power production to 100 per cent.
